The Dow had just gained 25 percent in 2017, and the Nasdaq had leapt 28 percent. Volatility was so low that there wasn’t a single day in 2017 when the S&P 500 fluctuated more than 2 percent.

articles.title: The Hedge Fund Manager Who Just Paid $238 Million for a Manhattan Penthouse

articles.content: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders Raises $10 Million in Less Than a Week
articles.content: A clutch of advisers to Senator Bernie Sanders began arriving at the Capitol Hill townhouse that served as his makeshift headquarters before dawn last Tuesday, where they readied themselves to track, among other things, the deluge of donations that would land after Mr. Sanders made his presidential campaign official.

articles.title: California Doesn’t Like Trump. But It May Need Him.
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: For Kamala Harris, a Strong Start, but With Some Notable Stumbles
articles.content: ANKENY, Iowa — When Senator Kamala Harris came to Iowa last month shortly after entering the presidential race, she surprised some in her own party by breezily stating her support for a single-payer health care plan that would end private insurance.

articles.title: Architects of Bernie Sanders’s 2016 Race Part Ways With 2020 Campaign
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The architects of the 2016 insurgent campaign for Senator Bernie Sanders abruptly parted ways with his 2020 campaign on Tuesday, dealing him a surprise blow one week after he entered the presidential race with an emphatic show of fund-raising strength.

articles.title: Restoring an Avenue in Paris Meant for Kings
articles.content: PARIS — The sidewalks are cracked along “la plus belle avenue du monde” — the most beautiful street in the world. Each day, 60,000 cars clog the lanes. Walkways are cluttered with abandoned scooters.

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler Plans Michigan Investment With 6,500 Jobs
articles.content: Even as analysts are forecasting declines in auto sales in the United States this year and next, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles believes the time is still ripe for expansion.

articles.title: Burned by Russia, Poland Turns to U.S. for Natural Gas and Energy Security
articles.content: SWINOUJSCIE, Poland — Gargantuan tankers pull into this port on the Baltic Sea twice a month, ferrying liquid natural gas from producers in Qatar, Norway and, increasingly, the United States. The fuel will help light and heat millions of Polish homes, while gradually cutting the country’s dependence on coal.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Chevron Thinks Men Can Fix the Diversity Problem
articles.content: Good Tuesday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

articles.title: How the Politically Unthinkable Can Become Mainstream
articles.content: You may have heard about the Overton window, and that’s not about to stop. With the political landscape shifting in sometimes startling ways, what was once an obscure idea has gained broader relevance.

articles.title: U.S. Loses Appeal Seeking to Block AT&T-Time Warner Merger
articles.content: The federal government on Tuesday lost its second court challenge to AT&T’s $85.4 billion merger with Time Warner, a blockbuster deal that has already begun to reshape much of the media industry.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
articles.content: $18 MILLION

articles.title: S.E.C. Asks Court to Hold Tesla’s Elon Musk in Contempt for Twitter Post on Production
articles.content: Elon Musk has put himself in legal trouble with a post on Twitter. Again.

articles.title: MWC 2019: Huawei Politics, Robots and Speedy 5G
articles.content: BARCELONA, Spain — The Trump administration sent a delegation to Spain this week to make its case against the Chinese technology company Huawei at one of the world’s biggest tech trade shows.

articles.title: F.T.C. Hits Musical.ly With Record Fine for Child Privacy Violation
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday announced a $5.7 million settlement with Musical.ly, a popular video social network now known as TikTok, over accusations that the company’s app illegally collected personal information about children.

articles.title: Could Elon Musk Talk Himself Into a Tesla Buyout?
articles.content: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.title: A Chain of Schools Is Cut Off From Student Loans, Leaving Thousands in Limbo
articles.content: Argosy University, a chain of vocationally focused schools with nearly two dozen campuses nationwide, teetered on the edge of collapse on Wednesday after the Education Department accused it of improperly taking as much as $16 million in aid money that should have gone to students.

articles.title: Arbitrator Scolds Fox and Orders It to Pay $178 Million to ‘Bones’ Team
articles.content: A private arbitrator ruled this month that Fox must pay the extraordinary sum of $178.7 million to former producers and stars of the procedural crime television series “Bones” in a dispute over profit participation.

articles.title: China Shifts, and Detroit’s Big Bet Goes Sour
articles.content: CHONGQING, China — For Detroit, China once meant opportunity. The country’s growing ranks of drivers bought cars by the millions. Its cheap labor gave American automakers dreams of someday exporting their Chinese-made cars to the United States. The Big Three bet billions of dollars there.

articles.title: Biden’s Family Is Urging Him to Run in 2020
articles.content: NEWARK, Del. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Tuesday that there’s “a consensus” in his family that he should run for president, but Mr. Biden said he did not want to embark on “a fool’s errand” and was still deliberating about whether to enter the race for the Democratic nomination.

articles.title: G.M. Backs Rule to Curb Carbon-Monoxide Risk in Keyless Cars
articles.content: Forgetting to shut off a keyless vehicle has been a safety hazard for years, causing a growing number of carbon-monoxide deaths. But a proposed regulation to require warning signals and other precautions has languished in the face of opposition from the auto industry.

articles.title: Trump Trade Adviser Defends China Deal Before Congressional Skeptics
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Robert Lighthizer, the president’s top trade adviser, cautioned lawmakers on Wednesday that hurdles remain to reaching a significant trade deal with China but said the administration’s talks represent the best hope for resetting economic terms between the two nations.

articles.title: Samsung Galaxy S10 Plus Review: A $1,000 Smartphone With Compromises
articles.content: After I set up Samsung’s new Galaxy S10 Plus phone last week, I showed it to my partner and said with atypical enthusiasm, “Check it out — this phone has the fingerprint sensor built directly into the screen.”

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Cohen Trashes Trump’s Business Image
articles.content: Good Thursday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Big Pharma’s Hunt for New Drugs Is Pushing Up Cost of Deals
articles.content: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.title: Dents Begin to Show at Top End of Classic Car Market
articles.content: Five years ago, the classic car market had just completed a turnaround that left even seasoned observers surprised by its speed. The deep recession that began in 2007 had dealt the same initial blow to vintage car prices that it did to the Dow and to the real estate market.

articles.title: Decision for 2020 Democrats: Should They Get in the Race Early, or Really Early?
articles.content: The country is 337 days away from the Iowa caucuses and 611 days from the general election for president. But that’s not stopping Democrats from debating the politics of entering the race really, really early or just, well, plain old-fashioned early.

articles.title: HBO’s C.E.O., an Emmy Magnet, Steps Down
articles.content: Richard Plepler, the gregarious chief executive of HBO and one of the most influential executives in entertainment, abruptly stepped down on Thursday. His decision came eight months after AT&T acquired Time Warner, the network’s corporate home, in an $85.4 billion deal.

articles.title: A New Editor, and a New Take on Brexit, for a Brawny London Tabloid
articles.content: LONDON — Just past the entrance to the airy headquarters of The Daily Mail, Britain’s pugnacious and politically powerful publication, stands a sculpture of three small spheres with wings. The title is hidden away on a small plaque: “Bullets of Information.”

articles.title: Facebook and Telegram Are Hoping to Succeed Where Bitcoin Failed
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Some of the world’s biggest internet messaging companies are hoping to succeed where cryptocurrency start-ups have failed by introducing mainstream consumers to the alternative world of digital coins.

articles.title: U.S. Economy Cooled as G.D.P. Grew at 2.6% Rate in Fourth Quarter
articles.content: The American economy slowed at the end of 2018 — and there could be a further slowdown to come.

articles.title: Beto O’Rourke Says He Has ‘Made a Decision’ on a Presidential Run
articles.content: Beto O’Rourke, who has turned his consideration of a presidential campaign into an online version of reality television, inviting Americans to follow along through journal dispatches as he travels the country in search of personal clarity, said Wednesday that he had made his decision.

articles.title: Live From America’s Capital, a TV Station Run by China’s Communist Party
articles.content: It broadcasts forced confessions to American audiences. It avoids subjects that displease Beijing. It cuts away when wind musses the hair of Xi Jinping, the Chinese president.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump Ordered Kushner’s Security Clearance
articles.content: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Lyft’s I.P.O. Filing Reveals Nearly $1 Billion in Losses
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Lyft pulled back the curtain on its business for the first time on Friday as it prepared to go public, officially starting the countdown on a horde of technology offerings that are set to bring new wealth to Silicon Valley this year.

articles.title: Jay Inslee, Washington Governor and Environmentalist, Enters 2020 Race
articles.content: SEATTLE — Jay Inslee, the governor of Washington and former member of Congress who has made climate change and the environment his signature issues, jumped into the crowded field of 2020 Democratic contenders for president on Friday.

articles.title: Michael Cohen’s Testimony Opens New Phase of Political Turbulence for Trump
articles.content: A small group of Republican strategists opposed to President Trump, branding themselves Defending Democracy Together, quietly conducted polling and focus groups last fall to gauge whether the president was vulnerable to a primary challenge in 2020. Assembling a presentation for sympathetic political donors, they listed points of weakness for Mr. Trump such as “tweeting/temperament” and “criminality/corruption.”

articles.title: Online and Making Thousands, at Age 4: Meet the Kidfluencers
articles.content: Samia was an influencer before she could talk.

articles.title: Gap Plans to Spin Off Old Navy After a Dismal Year
articles.content: Gap, one of the largest operators of mall stores in the United States, said on Thursday that it planned to spin off Old Navy into a separate public company, drawing a line between the family-friendly apparel chain and its classic, more expensive brands.

articles.title: U.K. Government to Pay Eurotunnel £33 Million Over Brexit Contracts
articles.content: LONDON — Add this to the list of headaches faced by Britain’s government as it frantically tries to prepare for Brexit: a 33 million pound (about $44 million) payment to settle a lawsuit brought by Eurotunnel, the company that operates the rail link between France and Britain.

articles.title: 5 Ways to Value Your Collection, Whether It’s Fine Wine or Shrunken Heads
articles.content: Bentley Meeker had amassed 4,500 bottles of wine by 2009 when the recession began to affect his lighting and event business. So, as painful as it was to part with some of the finest wines in his collection, he began selling them.

articles.title: These Loans Aim to Help Borrowers Build a Credit History
articles.content: Credit unions and community banks helped pioneer “credit-builder” loans that allow customers to establish credit histories and to begin growing their savings. Now, some start-ups are making similar loans more widely available, using digital technology.

articles.title: The Fall of ‘America’s Money Answers Man’
articles.content: Spin your radio dial, download a podcast or sit down at your next corporate gathering and you’ll have no trouble finding a self-styled financial guru to tell you what to do with your money.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From Michael Cohen’s testimony to the Trump-Kim Jong-un summit, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: Bernie Sanders Begins 2020 Race With Some Familiar Themes and a New One: Himself
articles.content: Many of the words Senator Bernie Sanders used in Brooklyn on Saturday as he kicked off his second run for president were familiar: “revolution,” “economic justice,” “prison-industrial complex.”

articles.title: For PG&E Board Candidate, ‘Job One Is to Restore the Public Trust’
articles.content: Phil Angelides may not appear to be the kind of person who would seek a seat on the board of Pacific Gas & Electric.

articles.title: Bigger, Saltier, Heavier: Fast Food Since 1986 in 3 Simple Charts
articles.content: Fast food chains have tried for years to woo health-conscious diners by mixing lighter fare like salads and yogurt with the usual burgers, fried chicken and shakes.

articles.title: Private Money Takes On Bigger Role in Airport Projects
articles.content: When Paine Field, about 25 miles north of Seattle in Everett, Wash., was born in the 1930s as a New Deal project, it was envisioned as a major commercial airport for the region. But that never happened. Instead, it became known as the place where Boeing offers “North America’s only publicly available commercial jet assembly plant tour.”

articles.title: Michael Jackson Documentary Revives Lurid Claims, Imperiling His Thriving Estate
articles.content: Michael Jackson’s damaged reputation began to recover the day he died.

articles.title: As Uber Prepares to Go Public, This Man Is Racing to Clean It Up
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Not long after Tony West joined Uber as chief legal officer in November 2017, he began a delicate task: crafting a transparency report to quantify how many people had been sexually assaulted during Uber rides.

articles.title: As Trump and Kim Met, North Korean Hackers Hit Over 100 Targets in U.S. and Ally Nations
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — North Korean hackers who have targeted American and European businesses for 18 months kept up their attacks last week even as President Trump was meeting with North Korea’s leader in Hanoi.

articles.title: Pennsylvania Democrats Wonder How Far Is Too Far Left in 2020
articles.content: SHALER, Pa. — This should be an upbeat moment for Pennsylvania Democrats, desperate to deprive President Trump of a second term.

articles.title: Why Napalm Is a Cautionary Tale for Tech Giants Pursuing Military Contracts
articles.content: Over the past few months, a fierce debate has erupted in Silicon Valley over whether large technology companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft should join forces with the United States military, along with agencies like Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

articles.title: Alphabet’s Security Start-Up Wants to Offer History Lessons
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Ten years ago, Google was hacked by the Chinese military in one of the most startling cyberattacks on an American company by government-affiliated agents.

articles.title: Judge Uses Rare Move to Throw Out Case Against Barclays Trader
articles.content: A federal judge in San Francisco took the rare step Monday of dismissing a market manipulation case against a Barclays trader before the jury rendered its verdict, a decision that will prevent federal prosecutors from filing an appeal.

articles.title: John Hickenlooper Says He Is Running in 2020, Citing a ‘Crisis of Division’
articles.content: DENVER — John Hickenlooper, the two-time Colorado governor and former brewpub owner who has overseen Colorado’s remarkable economic expansion, declared his candidacy for president on Monday.

articles.title: A.I. Wants to Know How You Plan a Trip
articles.content: At the Expedia Group product testing lab, facial recognition software gauges travelers’ feelings as they go through the process of booking hotel rooms online. The Swiss cruise company MSC Cruises is starting to use a virtual assistant to answer passengers’ questions. Designers from the boutique design and research firm the Gettys Group can show hotel executives new room layouts using virtual reality goggles, so hotels don’t need to build a full-scale model.

articles.title: U.S. and China Near a Trade Deal to Drop Tariffs
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is close to a trade deal with China that would roll back tariffs on both sides of the Pacific but may do little to achieve the substantive changes to China’s economy that the United States initially set out to win, people with knowledge of the talks said.

articles.title: Huawei Said to Be Preparing to Sue the U.S. Government
articles.content: SHANGHAI — The Chinese electronics giant Huawei is preparing to sue the United States government for barring federal agencies from using the company’s products, according to two people familiar with the matter.

articles.title: Ted Baker Chief, Ray Kelvin, Resigns Amid Harassment Claims
articles.content: LONDON — The founder and chief executive of the British fashion chain Ted Baker resigned on Monday after current and former employees accused him of inappropriate behavior.

articles.title: China Law Responds to U.S. Investment Demands. Critics Say It’s Not Enough.
articles.content: BEIJING — China is poised to approve a sweeping rewrite of the country’s laws on foreign investment that it hopes will help pacify the United States and ease a rancorous trade dispute. The new rules would respond to some concerns among foreign governments and businesses but disregard many other worries.

articles.title: Google Finds It’s Underpaying Many Men as It Addresses Wage Equity
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google conducted a study recently to determine whether the company was underpaying women and members of minority groups, it found, to the surprise of just about everyone, that men were paid less money than women for doing similar work.

articles.title: Papa John’s Founder, John Schnatter, to Leave Board After Nasty Leadership Fight
articles.content: A rancorous fight between John Schnatter, the former chairman of the Papa John’s pizza chain, and the company he founded appears to have been resolved, with Mr. Schnatter agreeing to give up his board seat after he helps choose an acceptable successor.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
DealBook Briefing: How China Is Trying to Fix Its Slowdown
articles.content: Good Tuesday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Revitalization Projects Reawaken Downtown Los Angeles
articles.content: Los Angeles’s downtown was little more than a sleepy office district not too long ago, where tens of thousands of suburbanites would clear out by the end of the workday and scores of classic Beaux-Arts and Art Deco buildings sat vacant or underutilized.

articles.title: Hillary Clinton Says She Is Not Running for President in 2020
articles.content: Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state and first lady who lost the White House to Donald J. Trump in 2016, said officially on Monday what has been unofficially clear for months: She is not running for president again in 2020.

articles.title: Colbert Beats Fallon for First Time in Key Ratings Demographic
articles.content: Stephen Colbert can finally claim complete bragging rights.

articles.title: Carlos Ghosn, Former Nissan Chairman, Nears Release From Jail
articles.content: Carlos Ghosn, the high-profile auto executive whose legal travails have riveted Japan and global investors, is poised to leave jail after a court granted his latest request for bail.

articles.title: F.D.A. Confirms Asbestos in Claire’s Products and Calls for Stronger Regulation
articles.content: The Food and Drug Administration warned on Tuesday that it had found asbestos in cosmetics sold by Claire’s, a retailer that markets jewelry and makeup to teenagers, and urged consumers not to use the products.

articles.title: On Politics: House Panel Opens Broad Trump Investigation
articles.content: Good Tuesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Facing Slowing Economic Growth, China’s Premier Promises Relief for Business
articles.content: BEIJING — China’s premier said on Tuesday that his government would respond to an economic slowdown by cutting taxes, easing burdens on the private sector and giving markets a bigger role — diluting the heavily pro-state pronouncements and policies that critics have warned were scaring investors.

articles.title: Democrats Reject Fox News as 2020 Debate Host, Citing Ties to Trump
articles.content: The Democratic National Committee said on Wednesday that it had barred Fox News from hosting or televising a candidate debate for the party’s 2020 primary election, an unusually pointed rebuke of a cable news channel whose star pundits are closely aligned with President Trump.

articles.title: Read Mark Zuckerberg’s Blog Post on His ‘Privacy-Focused Vision’ for Facebook
articles.content: [Read our analysis of Mr. Zuckerberg’s post.]

articles.title: Grab, a Southeast Asian Ride-Hailing Giant, Raises $1.5 Billion
articles.content: SHANGHAI — As Uber and Lyft prepare to become the world’s first publicly traded ride-hailing companies, their peers overseas are continuing to raise huge amounts of money through private investments.

articles.title: Tesla’s Troubles Mount: Shuttered Showrooms and Sinking Shares
articles.content: Tesla’s sleek stores embodied its green vision for upending the transportation and energy business: a one-stop shop for electric cars, solar panels and battery storage. Less than three months ago, the company announced 11 new store locations across the country.

articles.title: This Tech Makes D.I.Y. Key Duplication Easy. Maybe Too Easy.
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — A yellow booth with a screen caught my attention on a recent grocery trip. A blue ring on the contraption glowed, luring me toward it.

articles.title: Geneva Motor Show: A $19 Million Bugatti and Supercars to Spare
articles.content: GENEVA — The Geneva International Motor Show, getting underway this week, never lacks star power, but a one-of-a-kind Bugatti is outshining the mere supercars this year. “La Voiture Noire,” or “the Black Car,” was sold before the show even opened for $19 million, reputed to be the highest price ever paid for a new automobile.

articles.title: U.S. and E.U. Are Headed for a Food Fight Over Trade
articles.content: WASHINGTON — After a White House meeting last July, President Trump and Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission president, stepped into the Rose Garden and proclaimed they had a trade deal or, at the very least, the makings of a future pact.

articles.title: Carlos Ghosn, Former Nissan Chairman, Is Released on Bail in Japan
articles.content: TOKYO — Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan Motor chairman facing charges of financial wrongdoing in Japan, was released on bail on Wednesday after being held in a Tokyo jail since late November.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Carlos Ghosn Is Out of Jail
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Amazon Is Closing Pop-Up Stores, as Its Retail Strategy Evolves
articles.content: SEATTLE — Amazon is closing down its dozens of Pop-Up stores in the United States, as it both expands and tries to make sense of its growing retail operations.

articles.title: Spain’s Minimum Wage Just Jumped. The Debate Is Continuing.
articles.content: MADRID — As Spain grapples with a turbulent political crisis, one of Europe’s last Socialist governments may soon fall amid the rise of a new nationalism in the country. But whatever the outcome, Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez is leaving behind a signature legacy: a record increase in the minimum wage.

articles.title: The World’s Last Blockbuster Has No Plans to Close
articles.content: Fifteen years ago, a movie fan could go into any of Blockbuster’s 9,000 stores and walk out with a Steven Spielberg hit.

articles.title: Joe Biden’s 2020 Plan Is Almost Complete. Democrats Are Impatient.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The pieces for a Joseph R. Biden Jr. presidential campaign are falling into place: His nucleus of advisers has begun offering campaign positions to seasoned Democratic strategists. They are eyeing a headquarters in Delaware or nearby Philadelphia and a launch date in the beginning of April. Mr. Biden’s family is on board — his wife, Jill, enthusiastically so.

articles.title: Sherrod Brown Won’t Run for President in 2020
articles.content: Senator Sherrod Brown, the populist Ohio Democrat known for extolling the “dignity of work,” announced Thursday that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for president, ceding the primary field to other left-leaning candidates with broader national appeal.

articles.title: Chinese Officials Becoming Wary of a Quick Trade Deal
articles.content: BEIJING — President Trump says he is optimistic that a landmark trade deal with China is close. Chinese officials are not so sure.

articles.title: Airbnb Acquires HotelTonight to Expand Travel Portfolio
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb says it plans to acquire HotelTonight, a service for travelers seeking last-minute hotel bookings, in a deal that will expand the lodging-rental company’s portfolio with traditional and boutique hotel listings.

articles.title: WarnerMedia to Investigate Claims Involving a Top Executive
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — WarnerMedia said on Wednesday that it would conduct an “appropriate investigation” into allegations that Kevin Tsujihara, the chief executive of Warner Bros., pushed for a woman with whom he had a sexual relationship to be considered for roles in Warner films and television shows.

articles.title: What Kirsten Gillibrand Is Missing: New York Endorsements for 2020
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Senator Cory Booker has been endorsed for president by New Jersey’s entire 11-member Democratic congressional delegation, his state’s governor and its other senator. Senator Bernie Sanders has the backing of Vermont’s other senator and its lone House member. Senator Kamala Harris has support from three-quarters of the Democrats in the California State Senate, the governor and a handful of House members from her state.

articles.title: Chris Wallace of Fox News Calls Democrats’ Debate Ban ‘Shortsighted’
articles.content: Chris Wallace sounded a little bit wistful, and a little bit wry.

articles.title: Global Economy Slows, Pushing Europe’s Central Bank to Make a Surprise Move
articles.content: FRANKFURT — Just a few months ago, the European Central Bank put the brakes on a vast economic stimulus program devised during the financial crisis. On Thursday, it unexpectedly reversed course and revived some of the measures, signaling the rising threat of a recession.

articles.title: Mark Zuckerberg Wants Facebook to Emulate WeChat. Can It?
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — As Mark Zuckerberg begins shifting Facebook to private messaging and away from public sharing and open conversations, the vision he has sketched out for the future of social networking already exists — just not in the United States.

articles.title: What Will a Contempt Hearing Mean for Tesla’s Elon Musk?
articles.content: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.title: Amazon Said to Team Up With Yankees in Bid for YES Network
articles.content: Amazon is coming to New York — to grab a piece of the Yankees sports network.

articles.title: LaCroix Maker’s Profit Slips. C.E.O. Blames ‘Injustice.’ Stock Dives.
articles.content: The latest news release from the maker of LaCroix sparkling water was quirkier than usual, which is notable for a company whose public statements routinely feature exclamation marks, florid adjectives and colorful fonts that seem lifted straight off a Tumblr page.

articles.title: The Allure, and Burden, of Private Equity
articles.content: Private equity offers the promise of exclusive deals, outsize returns and enviable cocktail parties.

articles.title: The Jobs Report Was the Weakest in Months. Here’s Why.
articles.content: The economy’s remarkably steady job-creation machine sputtered in February and produced a mere 20,000 jobs. It was the smallest gain in well over a year and came on top of other signs that the economy was off to a sluggish start in 2019.

articles.title: Facing Legal Scrutiny, China’s State TV Recalls Its U.S. Head
articles.content: China’s state broadcaster is recalling the head of its American arm and more than a dozen other employees back to China in a leadership shake-up as scrutiny grows in the United States over the unit’s connections to Beijing.

articles.title: The Week in Tech: Facebook’s Privacy Pivot (Business Model Not Included)
articles.content: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

articles.title: Endeavor Returns Money to Saudi Arabia, Protesting Khashoggi Murder
articles.content: There was much to celebrate last spring when Ariel Emanuel, the chief executive of the talent agency Endeavor, helped throw a splashy Hollywood party for Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman.

articles.title: Amid Media Storm, Carlos Ghosn’s Lawyer Apologizes for Disguise
articles.content: A lawyer for Carlos Ghosn issued an apology Friday to try to calm a media storm over a disguise worn by the former car executive as he left jail.

articles.title: The Bull Market Began 10 Years Ago. Why Aren’t More People Celebrating?
articles.content: The financial system had nearly collapsed. The deepest recession in decades was devouring over 700,000 jobs a month. Roughly $13 trillion in stock market wealth, slowly rebuilt since the dot-com bust, had again been incinerated.

articles.title: Amy Klobuchar Talks Health Care, Israel and, Yes, That Comb
articles.content: There was no real doubt what the first question to Senator Amy Klobuchar would be.

articles.title: F.A.A. Cautions Southwest Airlines and Mechanics Union in Contract Dispute
articles.content: The Federal Aviation Administration has warned Southwest Airlines and its mechanics union that their legal dispute could end up damaging the safety of the airline.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From the president’s checks to a resolution against hate, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: In Silicon Valley, Plans for a Monument to Silicon Valley
articles.content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Paris has the Eiffel Tower. St. Louis is inseparable from the Gateway Arch. Seattle boasts the Space Needle. Washington has its Monument.

articles.title: The Bull Market’s Greatest Feat? Sowing Doubt
articles.content: Ten years ago, when the global financial crisis seemed at its worst, the stock market hit rock bottom.

articles.title: Walmart Vendor’s Employees Face F.B.I. Inquiry for Snooping on Retailer’s Internal Emails
articles.content: The F.B.I. is investigating whether employees of one of Walmart’s technology contractors obtained sensitive information by monitoring email accounts at the retail giant, including those of several executives.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders-Style Politics Are Defining 2020 Race, Unnerving Moderates
articles.content: [Sign up for our politics newsletter and join our conversation about the 2020 presidential race.]

articles.title: Wells Fargo Says Its Culture Has Changed. Some Employees Disagree.
articles.content: Wells Fargo has spent years publicly apologizing for deceiving customers with fake bank accounts, unwarranted fees and unwanted products. Its top executives say that because they have eliminated the aggressive sales targets that spurred bad behavior, the bank’s culture has changed.

articles.title: India Fights Diabetic Blindness With Help From A.I.
articles.content: MADURAI, India — The Aravind Eye Hospital will treat anyone who comes through the door, with or without money.

articles.title: Stores See a Future Without ‘May I Help You?’ (They’ll Already Have Your Data)
articles.content: LAS VEGAS — The chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue’s parent company said stores would eventually recognize customers as soon as they walked in. FedEx showcased a robot that it thinks could ultimately make same-day deliveries on its own. The mall operator Macerich described the movable walls and fixtures that it was using to construct new stores for online-only brands.

articles.title: As Hillary Clinton Steps Away, a Political Era for Women Wanes
articles.content: [Sign up for our politics newsletter and join our conversation about the 2020 presidential race.]

articles.title: U.S. and China Near Currency Deal, but Provisions May Not Be New
articles.content: BEIJING — A pending trade agreement between the United States and China could put few restrictions on Beijing’s control over the strength of its currency, potentially inflaming trade hawks in Congress and within the Trump administration itself.

articles.title: Automakers Retool Marketing Machines as They Go Electric
articles.content: Geneva — After years of promising electric cars, established carmakers are actually starting to build them.

articles.title: Biden and Sanders Lead the 2020 Field in Iowa, Poll Finds
articles.content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders lead a new poll of likely Iowa caucusgoers released this weekend, underscoring how the nomination process for the Democratic Party has, to this early point, been defined by the two figures with the largest national profiles.

articles.title: Boeing Faces Questions About Its New 737 Max Jets After Ethiopia Crash

articles.title: DealBook Special: Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week

articles.title: Biden Makes First Campaign Appearance in South Carolina, Key Primary State
articles.content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — South Carolina residents gave former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. a front-runner’s welcome Saturday afternoon, when his recently announced presidential campaign made its first stop in the early primary state that will play a critical role in determining the Democratic presidential nominee.

articles.title: Shake-Up Looms at CBS News, as a Celebrated New Boss Makes Her Mark
articles.content: When Susan Zirinsky was named the new president of CBS’s troubled news division in January, she said she wanted to unite her team “both functionally and spiritually.”

articles.title: Occidental Ups Its Cash Offer for Anadarko
articles.content: HOUSTON — Occidental Petroleum fortified its bid for Anadarko Petroleum on Sunday night with more cash in its latest effort to outbid Chevron and win the support of Anadarko’s shareholders who may well make the final decision on a merger.

articles.title: Breaking the News to Mom and Dad: I’m Selling Weed (Legally)

articles.title: Warren Buffett’s Case for Capitalism

articles.content: DUBLIN — Inside a large room in Facebook’s European headquarters in Ireland’s capital, about 40 employees sit at rows of desks, many with two computer screens and a sign representing a country in the European Union.

articles.title: Ride-Sharing’s Future? It May Sit on Electric Motorbikes
articles.content: BANGALORE, India — In Uber’s vision of the future, self-driving cars will whisk us everywhere, eliminating the need for its millions of human drivers.

articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump, emboldened by a strong American economy and wary of criticism that an evolving trade deal with China would not adequately benefit the United States, threatened on Sunday to impose more punishing tariffs on Chinese goods in an attempt to force additional concessions in a final agreement.

articles.title: DealBook Special: Everything You Need to Know About the Uber I.P.O.

articles.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to Rally for Green New Deal in Washington
articles.content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the popular freshman Democrat from New York who is trying to use her star power to move the Democratic Party to the left, will headline a rally next week in Washington in favor of the Green New Deal, as she seeks to shore up support for the expansive climate legislation that has been met with skepticism by members of both parties.

articles.title: Europe Is Reining In Tech Giants. But Some Say It’s Going Too Far.
articles.content: LONDON — In Spain, activists were convicted for social media posts that violated an expanded antiterrorism law. The Twitter accounts of German citizens were blocked because of rules enacted last year that prohibit hate speech. And a Dutch court determined Google must remove search results about a doctor punished for poor performance, in compliance with a privacy law.

articles.title: Biden’s 2020 Rivals Attack Him From the Left on Climate Change

articles.title: Trump Has a Strong Economy to Proclaim. In Wisconsin, It Just Might Work.
articles.content: COLFAX, Wis. — President Trump came to Wisconsin late last month to boast about the state’s unemployment rate, which has been at or near 3 percent for more than a year. “It’s never been this low before. Ever, ever, ever,” he said. (Fact check: true.)

articles.title: U.S.-China Trade Talks Stumble on Beijing’s Spending at Home

articles.content: Julián Castro, whose campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has so far struggled to gain much momentum, unveiled a proposal Monday to create a national, federally funded prekindergarten program, eliminate tuition at public universities and community colleges and alter the student-debt repayment process, part of a sweeping policy plan that his campaign hopes could reshape public education.

articles.title: New Tax Will Help Washington Residents Pay for Long-Term Care
articles.content: Eligible residents who live in Washington State will have a new benefit available to them starting in 2025: a $100-per-day allowance for a variety of long-term care services, which will last up to a year.

articles.content: A jury in Oakland, Calif., ordered Monsanto on Monday to pay a couple more than $2 billion in damages after finding that its Roundup weed killer caused their cancer — the third jury to conclude that the company failed to warn consumers of its flagship product’s dangers.

articles.title: Mayor and ‘Foreign Minister’: How Bernie Sanders Brought the Cold War to Burlington
articles.content: BURLINGTON, Vt. — For Daniel Ortega, the president of Nicaragua, the summer of 1985 was to be a moment of extraordinary triumph. In July, on the sixth anniversary of the Sandinista revolution, Mr. Ortega would address a crowd of hundreds of thousands with a message of defiance for his political nemesis, Ronald Reagan, and the Contra militias waging war on him with support from Washington.

articles.title: Boeing 737 Max Simulators Are in High Demand. They Are Flawed.
articles.content: Since the two fatal crashes of the Boeing 737 Max, airlines around the world have moved to buy flight simulators to train their pilots.

articles.title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise to Acquire Supercomputer Pioneer Cray
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett Packard Enterprise said Friday that it would buy the supercomputer pioneer Cray, a relatively tiny financial transaction that could loom large in a quickening race between the United States and China at the highest reaches of computing.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump Does Not Want Military Clash With Iran
articles.content: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Interest Rates on New Federal Student Loans Will Dip Slightly
articles.content: College borrowers will get a small break in the coming school year, as interest rates on new federal student loans fall slightly this summer.

articles.title: Knopf Fires High-Profile Editor Over Policy Breach
articles.content: Alfred A. Knopf has fired a longtime editor who worked with such literary stars as Raymond Carver, Annie Dillard and Cormac McCarthy in what it called a breach of company policy.

articles.title: After Alabama Abortion Law, 3 Democrats Propose a New Strategy
articles.content: Responding to a series of highly restrictive abortion laws aimed at overturning Roe v. Wade, several Democratic presidential candidates have called on Congress to codify abortion rights, signaling a newly aggressive approach in a debate whose terms have long been set by conservatives.

articles.title: Trump Lifts Metal Tariffs and Delays Auto Levies, Limiting Global Trade Fight
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump agreed on Friday to lift tariffs on metal imports from Mexico and Canada, removing a major irritant for two important allies that in exchange agreed to stop punishing American farmers with their own taxes on pork, cheese and milk.

articles.title: Biden Delivers Call for National Unity at Philadelphia Rally
articles.content: PHILADELPHIA — Joseph R. Biden Jr., sometimes known to Democrats in this city as Pennsylvania’s “third senator,” returned to the state of his birth on Saturday to deliver a forceful call for national unity, looking past the Democratic presidential primary to directly appeal to the voters who helped power President Trump’s victory in Pennsylvania and across the country in 2016.

articles.title: Running Scared: Network TV in the Streaming Age
articles.content: As the curtain comes down on the 2018-19 television season, the major broadcast networks found themselves sinking deeper into trouble.

articles.title: ‘I Did My Best to Stop American Foreign Policy’: Bernie Sanders on the 1980s
articles.content: As Burlington’s mayor from 1981 to 1989, Bernie Sanders tried to infuse local politics with international issues. From his earliest days in office, Mr. Sanders aimed to execute his own foreign policy, repudiating President Ronald Reagan’s aggressive support for anti-communist governments and resistance forces, while going further than many Democrats in backing socialist leaders.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From rising tensions with Iran to the still-growing Democratic presidential field, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: As ‘Rocketman’ Prepares to Take Off, Hollywood Holds Its Breath
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Multiple movie studios passed on the opportunity to make “Rocketman,” an R-rated musical fantasia about Elton John’s hedonistic breakthrough years. Too gay. Too expensive. Too reliant on an unproven star.

articles.title: Harry Reid Remembers One Impeachment and Ponders a Second
articles.content: LAS VEGAS — Former Senator Harry Reid of Nevada has called President Trump the “worst president” in American history. Mr. Trump has said the former Senate Democratic leader’s “failed career” was marked by “lies and deception.”

articles.title: Who Is Robert F. Smith, the Man Paying Off Morehouse Graduates’ Loans?
articles.content: Robert F. Smith was giving the commencement address to the graduating class of Morehouse College when he made a surprise announcement: He would be paying off the student loans of the roughly 400 graduates.

articles.title: Kissing Babies, Loving Scrapple, Fighting Viral Hoaxes: ’20 Race’s New Routine
articles.content: It’s unlikely you have heard of @ToTheXToTheY. But you may be familiar with its work.

articles.title: Tech Jobs Lead to the Middle Class. Just Not for the Masses.
articles.content: Brittney Ball was living in a homeless shelter with her baby when she learned of a one-year program offering technical training, professional skills and an internship. She took the plunge.

articles.title: Deutsche Bank Staff Saw Suspicious Activity in Trump and Kushner Accounts
articles.content: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Anti-money-laundering specialists at Deutsche Bank recommended in 2016 and 2017 that multiple transactions involving legal entities controlled by Donald J. Trump and his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, be reported to a federal financial-crimes watchdog.

articles.title: Abortion Fight or Strong Economy? For G.O.P., Cultural Issues Undercut 2020 Message
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The unemployment rate is at a 50-year low, companies are adding jobs and the gross domestic product grew by 3.2 percent in the first quarter, undercutting predictions of a coming recession.

articles.title: 16-Year-Olds Want a Vote. Fifty Years Ago, So Did 18-Year-Olds.
articles.content: JAMESBURG, N.J. — Stuart Goldstein still has the red-and-white bumper stickers and other artifacts from 1969, when he helped persuade New Jersey lawmakers that 18-year-olds should be able to vote.

articles.title: Amazon Faces Investor Pressure Over Facial Recognition
articles.content: Facial recognition software is coming under increasing scrutiny from civil liberties groups and lawmakers. Now Amazon, one of the most visible purveyors of the technology, is facing pressure from another corner as well: its own shareholders.

articles.title: Kamala Harris Announces Plan to Close the Gender Pay Gap
articles.content: Senator Kamala Harris of California on Monday announced a proposal to close the gender wage gap by requiring larger companies to certify that men and women are paid equally, in an effort to combat wage discrimination on a federal level.

articles.title: As Huawei Loses Google, the U.S.-China Tech Cold War Gets Its Iron Curtain
articles.content: China has spent nearly two decades building a digital wall between itself and the rest of the world, a one-way barrier designed to keep out foreign companies like Facebook and Google while allowing Chinese rivals to leave home and expand across the world.

articles.title: T-Mobile-Sprint Merger Wins Approval of F.C.C. Chairman
articles.content: T-Mobile and Sprint moved a step closer on Monday to completing their long-sought merger, securing the public support of the Federal Communications Commission’s chairman for a deal that would reshape the country’s wireless industry.

articles.title: Whitney Houston’s Estate Plans a Hologram Tour and a New Album
articles.content: Since Whitney Houston died in 2012, her estate has been pitched every kind of entertainment deal, from jukebox musicals to a traveling museum.

articles.title: Tech Stocks Sink After Google Cuts Huawei Off Android Support
articles.content: Technology shares led the broader market lower on Monday, as a Trump administration order effectively barring American companies from selling components and software to the Chinese technology giant Huawei rippled through Wall Street.

articles.title: Fox News Welcomes Pete Buttigieg. Trump and ‘Fox & Friends’ Aren’t Pleased.
articles.content: The night began with a campaign-style biographical video and ended with a standing ovation. The candidate called President Trump’s behavior “grotesque” and lamented the “media noise machine on the right wing.” He attacked Tucker Carlson and Laura Ingraham by name.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump and Kushner Raised Flags at Deutsche Bank
articles.content: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Did Anti-Abortion Activists Overreach in Alabama?
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: Google Changes Abortion Ad Policy
articles.content: Advertisers planning to run ads on Google referring to abortion services in the United States, Britain and Ireland must first get clearance from the search giant, the company said in an online post.

articles.title: Southwest Airlines Mechanics Approve Contract, Ending Long Impasse
articles.content: The union representing about 2,500 Southwest Airlines mechanics voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to ratify a new contract proposal, ending a labor impasse that lasted nearly seven years and wound up in court twice.

articles.title: New Coke Was a Debacle. It’s Coming Back. Blame ‘Stranger Things.’
articles.content: New Coke, the soft drink that drew a nationwide backlash in 1985, is back. And the credit, or blame, for the return of Coca-Cola’s greatest folly goes to Netflix.

articles.title: Revitalizing Montgomery as It Embraces Its Past
articles.content: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — No other Southern city is arguably tied as closely to the history of race relations in America as Alabama’s capital, considered to be the birthplace of the civil rights movement. Not until recently, though, have the story of suffering and the response from activists translated into economic benefit for the 200-year-old river city.

articles.title: Trump Team Vets Fed Critic for Board Seat
articles.content: The Trump administration is vetting Judy Shelton, a conservative economist and former Trump campaign adviser, for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board, according to people familiar with the matter, putting the longtime Fed critic one step closer to a leadership role at an institution she would like to drastically change.

articles.title: As Biden Rakes In Big Money, Will There Be a Political Cost?
articles.content: A couple of days before Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced his campaign for president, he spent 45 minutes on the phone with John Morgan, a major Florida political donor. As they chatted, Mr. Morgan suggested that the former vice president would be jealous to know that he was lounging poolside, a cigar in hand, with his two German shepherds by his side.

articles.title: On Politics: Secrecy Fight Between Trump and Congress Escalates
articles.content: Good Tuesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Jamie Oliver’s U.K. Restaurants Declare Bankruptcy
articles.content: LONDON — The celebrity chef Jamie Oliver put his British restaurants into administration, a form of bankruptcy protection, on Tuesday, after the chain struggled with debt and an increasingly saturated market in recent years.

articles.title: Democrats’ Tax Cuts Target Middle Class More Than Trump’s, Study Says
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Tax plans from several Democratic candidates for president would cost less than President Trump’s signature tax cuts but deliver larger benefits to most low- and middle-income Americans, according to a new analysis by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a liberal think tank in Washington.

articles.title: At a Historic Moment for Asian-American Candidates, Andrew Yang Leans In
articles.content: They broke into cheers every time he referred to numbers or statistics. They chanted “PowerPoint! PowerPoint!” when he renewed a pledge to use the program to deliver the State of the Union.

articles.title: Boeing Faces Compensation Demand From China’s Biggest Airlines
articles.content: BEIJING — Boeing is facing compensation claims from the three biggest airlines in China, which have grounded dozens of 737 Max jetliners since the deadly crash of an Ethiopian Airlines flight in March.

articles.title: Google’s Duplex Uses A.I. to Mimic Humans (Sometimes)
articles.content: ALBANY, Calif. — On a recent afternoon at the Lao Thai Kitchen restaurant, the telephone rang and the caller ID read “Google Assistant.” Jimmy Tran, a waiter, answered the phone. The caller was a man with an Irish accent hoping to book a dinner reservation for two on the weekend.

articles.title: Amazon Investors Reject Proposals on Climate Change and Facial Recognition
articles.content: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Wednesday that its shareholders had voted down proposals that would have pushed the company to reconsider its societal impact in two key areas: facial recognition and climate change.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump May Impose Limits on Chinese Maker of Surveillance Tech
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Kirsten Gillibrand Proposes Huge Investments in Maternal Health, Child Care and Education
articles.content: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand’s presidential campaign on Wednesday introduced a proposal aimed at investing heavily in maternal and child health, adoption and in vitro fertilization, paid family leave and universal prekindergarten.

articles.title: Mobile Carriers in Britain and Japan Begin to Turn Away From Huawei
articles.content: LONDON — Google’s decision to cut off support to Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant blacklisted by the Trump administration, is rippling across the globe as companies suspend ties to the handset maker.

articles.title: Canceled Fund-Raiser Prompts Question: Can a Democrat Oppose Abortion?
articles.content: CHICAGO — A top Democratic official on Wednesday canceled a planned fund-raiser for an anti-abortion congressman that had prompted an outcry among progressives, raising the question of whether there is room left in the party for lawmakers who oppose abortion at a moment when numerous Republican-controlled states are trying to effectively outlaw the procedure.

articles.title: Saudi Arabia Negotiating to Buy U.S. Natural Gas From Sempra Energy
articles.content: Saudi Arabia is planning to buy large volumes of American natural gas for the first time, signaling a new strategy for its state-owned company Saudi Aramco and the growing importance of the United States as an energy exporter.

articles.title: Trump Gives Farmers $16 Billion in Aid Amid Prolonged China Trade War
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday unveiled a $16 billion bailout for farmers hurt by his trade war with Beijing, signaling a protracted fight ahead that is already prompting some American companies to shift business away from China.

articles.title: 2020 Democrats Join McDonald’s Workers Striking Over Wages and Harassment
articles.content: As McDonald’s held its annual shareholder meeting on Thursday, several Democratic presidential candidates joined striking workers demanding a $15 minimum wage, union rights and better protection from sexual harassment.

articles.title: Deutsche Bank Leaders, Facing Angry Investors, Survive Vote
articles.content: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank shareholders had plenty of reasons to be unhappy as they converged in a Frankfurt concert hall Thursday for the troubled lender’s annual meeting.

articles.title: Motorcycles With One Foot in the Future and One in the Past
articles.content: GOSHEN, Ind. — Downtown Goshen looks much the same as it did when American-built motorcycles from the likes of Merkel, Thor and Henderson first startled horse traffic.

articles.title: To Get Boeing 737 Max Flying, Global Consensus Will Be Hard
articles.content: FORT WORTH — Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration want global consensus to get the 737 Max flying again. They may have to wait a while.

articles.title: Esquire’s Editor Is Out in Reshuffling at Hearst Magazines
articles.content: Jay Fielden is leaving his position as Esquire’s editor in chief, a job he held for three years, Hearst Magazines announced Thursday. The change at the venerable men’s publication, which started in 1933, is part of a reshuffling under Troy Young, who became president of the publisher in July.

articles.title: Facebook Says It Is More Aggressively Enforcing Content Rules
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, facing withering criticism from governments around the world, said Thursday that it had been more aggressive in recent months about scrubbing its platform of hate speech.

articles.title: Sanders’s Education Plan Renews Debate Over Charter Schools and Segregation
articles.content: When Senator Bernie Sanders delivered a wide-ranging speech on education Saturday, he became the first major Democratic candidate to propose a detailed plan to racially integrate schools, calling for $1 billion in funding to support local integration efforts, such as magnet schools and busing.

articles.title: As California Wildfire Season Looms, Finding Tree Trimmers Is a New Problem
articles.content: OAKHURST, Calif. — Pacific Gas & Electric has a big problem. Its equipment keeps coming into contact with dry trees and shrubs and starting devastating wildfires. So the company is scrambling to trim or cut down hundreds of thousands of trees across its vast Northern California territory.

articles.title: It’s Almost ‘529 Day,’ and States Say Don’t Forget This College Savings Gift
articles.content: College savings plans in many states are gearing up for their annual “529 Day” on Wednesday, when they offer incentives and promotions to encourage families to open and contribute to the special accounts.

articles.title: Trump Administration to Expand Penalties for Currency Manipulators
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said Thursday that it planned to penalize countries that undervalue their currencies, the latest effort to prevent foreign competitors from trying to undercut American producers and import cheap goods into the United States.

articles.title: Climate Change Is Catching On With Voters. Why Isn’t Jay Inslee?
articles.content: RAYMOND, N.H. — For years, climate change was an issue of passionate concern to a few voters, but never enough to ripple presidential politics. The Hillary Clinton-Donald Trump debates in 2016 notoriously did not include any questions from moderators about global warming.

articles.title: More Turmoil at The Markup, a Tech Site Still in Beta Mode
articles.content: One month after the top editor was ousted from The Markup, a fledgling nonprofit investigative tech news site, amid disagreements with the other two founders, more turbulence followed.

articles.title: On Politics: The Trade War Is Here to Stay
articles.content: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: The Rise of the Summer Sequel
articles.content: This summer, at least 14 major-studio sequels will hit theaters, and many of them will likely rule the box office — continuing a decades-long shift in Hollywood toward the film franchise.

articles.title: Pain of Tariffs Tests Farmers’ Faith in Trump: ‘How Long Is Short-Term?’
articles.content: OSSEO, Wis. — From the start, President Trump’s combative trade strategy toward China has carried the promise that short-term pain inflicted on farmers would be worth the longer-term gains for American producers, from agriculture to technology.

articles.title: Huawei Ban Threatens Wireless Service in Rural Areas
articles.content: OPHEIM, Mont. — Kevin Nelson was recently in the middle of his 3,800-acre farm in northeast Montana, where the landscape stretches out like an ocean, when his tractor broke. He tried to find a cellular signal strong enough to send a photo of the broken part to a repair shop 65 miles away, but failed.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders, No Longer the Front-Runner, Brings Campaign Home to Vermont
articles.content: MONTPELIER, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders returned to his home state on Saturday for the first time since he declared in February that he was running for president again, displaying the uncompromisingly liberal defiance that many of those in the audience have been hearing for decades.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From President Trump’s stonewalling of Congress to the trade war with China, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler and Renault in Talks on Possible Alliance
articles.content: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the French carmaker Renault are holding discussions about a possible alliance aimed at strengthening both companies’ competitiveness in Europe and other parts of the world, a person familiar with the matter said on Saturday.

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler Set to Propose a Merger With Renault
articles.content: Fiat Chrysler is planning to propose a merger with the French carmaker Renault on Monday, according to two people involved in the negotiations, in a transaction that could reshape the global automobile industry.

articles.title: Cory Booker Says Beating Trump Should Be ‘the Floor, Not the Ceiling’
articles.content: BURLINGTON, Iowa — As Senator Cory Booker swept through Iowa on a four-day visit over Memorial Day weekend, he called on his often overflowing crowds to approach the presidential primary campaign through a new paradigm.

articles.title: Craft Brewers Lighten Up and Take Aim at the ‘Sweaty Consumer’
articles.content: For Sam Calagione, a founder of the craft brewery Dogfish Head, his company’s efforts to get healthier had a selfish origin.

articles.title: With the 2020 Democratic Field Set, Candidates Begin the Races Within the Race
articles.content: NEWTON, Iowa — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has built an early lead in the month since he entered the presidential campaign, confidently projecting himself as the Democratic front-runner and the candidate best positioned to defeat President Trump.

articles.title: Brexit Is Sending Students Packing, Straining Private Schools on Both Ends
articles.content: LONDON — For years Dover College, on the southeast coast of England, has attracted a steady flow of summer students from across the channel, with parents willing to pay for their children to learn English in a boarding school environment.

articles.title: Renault Considering Fiat’s Offer to Merge Into a New Auto Giant
articles.content: The French carmaker Renault said on Monday that it was considering a proposal by Fiat Chrysler to merge and form a global partnership aimed at improving their chances of surviving the coming perilous and costly shift to electric and self-driving cars.

articles.title: Rise in Unruly Behavior on Planes Is Tied to Stress of Flying
articles.content: Flying has increasingly become a world of the haves and have-nots, starting with purchasing a ticket and continuing as passengers are sorted by status to board.

articles.title: McKinsey Said Disclosure Rules Were Confusing. It Ignored Its Own Primer.
articles.content: McKinsey & Company has spent months fighting in court over how it should disclose potential conflicts of interest when it advises bankrupt companies. The powerful consulting firm has defended itself by arguing that federal disclosure rules are so vague and confusing that almost no one can agree on how to comply.

articles.title: As E-Sports Grow, So Do Their Homes
articles.content: The rise of e-sports is no surprise to anyone who has followed the video game industry. They are expected to bring in more than $1 billion in global revenue this year, as millions of fans watch hundreds of events from all over.

articles.title: Sports Illustrated, the Brand, Is Sold for $110 Million
articles.content: The intellectual property of Sports Illustrated, the magazine whose monumental covers and narrative voices have helped define American sports since its debut 65 years ago, has been sold for $110 million to Authentic Brands Group, in an unusual transaction that suggests the magazine’s most coveted asset is its brand.

articles.title: Food Delivery Apps Are Drowning China in Plastic
articles.content: BEIJING — In all likelihood, the enduring physical legacy of China’s internet boom will not be the glass-and-steel office complexes or the fancy apartments for tech elites.

articles.title: Google’s Shadow Work Force: Temps Who Outnumber Full-Time Employees
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Mindy Cruz had an offer for a full-time position at another big tech company when she accepted a temporary job as a recruiter at Google in 2017. The pay was less and the benefits were not as good, but it was one step closer to her dream of becoming a Google employee.

articles.content: Good Tuesday morning, and welcome back after the long weekend. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Savior of G.M. Lordstown Plant, Hailed by Trump, Is a Corporate Cipher
articles.content: For months, President Trump had been putting pressure on the chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra, because she had decided to idle an Ohio factory and lay off 1,600 workers. “I am not happy that it is closed when everything else in our Country is BOOMING,” he said on Twitter. “I asked her to sell it or do something quickly.”
