articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Gains Ground in 2020 Field, One Plan at a Time
articles.content: NEWTON, Iowa — To the crowd of Iowans gathered in a school gym on Saturday night, Senator Elizabeth Warren made a request: They should pose a question to the other presidential candidates who come to Iowa seeking their vote.

articles.title: Trump and Biden Campaign Trade Jabs Over North Korea’s Remarks
articles.content: HOUSTON — President Trump sided again on Tuesday with the government of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in mocking Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s intelligence, an extraordinary alignment of a United States president and an authoritarian regime against an American politician — and an insult that Mr. Biden pooh-poohed by letting an aide rebut it.

articles.title: This Boutique Bike Shop Shows How Trump’s Tariffs Can Hit the Little Guy
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Shane Cusick started his small business, Pello, in 2014 with the goal of making lightweight bikes for children. His experience over the past year is a case study in how a trade war can disrupt a fledgling enterprise.

articles.title: Apps That Blast Out Crime Alerts Don’t Have to Rattle You
articles.content: My phone recently buzzed with an alarming notification: Police officers were responding to a shooting about a mile away.

articles.title: Democratic Party Will Impose Tougher Rules for Qualifying for Third Debate
articles.content: The national Democratic Party will toughen the requirements for participating in the presidential primary debates this fall, a decision likely to prompt blowback from candidates struggling to gain a foothold in the crowded race.

articles.title: On Migrant Journeys With WhatsApp and Google Translate
articles.content: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Miriam Jordan, a national immigration correspondent based in Los Angeles, discussed the tech she’s using.

articles.title: After Mueller’s Remarks, More 2020 Democrats Call for Impeachment
articles.content: Robert S. Mueller III’s statement on Wednesday, in which he reiterated the conclusions of his investigation and declined to clear President Trump, seemed to open a dam in the Democratic presidential field.

articles.title: Pokémon Sleep Wants to Make Snoozing a Game Too
articles.content: HONG KONG — For a few heady months in 2016, Pokémon Go transformed the morning commute for millions of people into a critter-hunting safari, populating the ordinary world with a reality-augmented menagerie of Pikachus, Charmanders and Eevees.

articles.title: On Politics: Supreme Court Sidesteps Abortion Question
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Huawei Revs Up Its U.S. Lawsuit, With the Media in Mind
articles.content: SHANGHAI — Huawei is ramping up its legal challenge to American limits on purchases of its equipment, in a sign that it is doubling down on its strategy of fighting the Trump administration through the courts and public opinion rather than through quiet negotiations.

articles.title: New York Regulator to Investigate Exposure of Mortgage Documents
articles.content: A New York State financial regulator is investigating a security vulnerability at First American Financial Corporation, a title insurance company, that exposed an estimated 885 million records related to mortgage deals.

articles.title: Victory for Fathers in a Parental Leave Case That Could Be a Harbinger
articles.content: For years, scholars, activists and mothers have criticized policies that place the burden of child-rearing overwhelmingly on women. Increasingly, fathers are joining the criticism of these policies — and asserting their legal rights to challenge them.

articles.title: Yes, India’s Economy Is Growing, but Can You Trust the Data?
articles.content: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India won re-election last week with what seemed to be rousing support for his market-oriented economic policies — yet few in India can agree on just how much growth or unemployment occurred in his first term.

articles.title: On Politics: Mueller Breaks His Silence
articles.content: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: The 2020 Race Is Testing Progressives’ Power. They’re Pushing Back.
articles.content: Optimism filled the Prospect Park air as more than 100 supporters of Senator Elizabeth Warren’s presidential campaign gathered last week for an organizing event called “How to Be All In for Elizabeth.” But as dusk approached, the final “She Has a Plan” button was handed out, and the crowd of mostly millennial Brooklynites began to disperse, hope gave way to skepticism.

articles.title: Apps Purged by Apple Say It Holds the Key They Need to Get Back In
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Last year, Apple announced that it had created tools to help people limit the time they and their children spent on their iPhones. Around the same time, Apple began purging from its App Store a number of apps that offered similar services.

articles.title: The Split-Screen Primary
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: Hillary Clinton, in Graduation Speech, Calls for Renewed Focus on Russian Interference
articles.content: Hours after Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, broke his silence and said that Russia had sought to damage Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign, Mrs. Clinton said that the “systemic efforts to interfere” in the 2016 election “deserves the attention of every American.”

articles.title: Fed May Consider Lower Rates if Inflation and Global Risks Worsen
articles.content: Growing economic risks from President Trump’s trade war with China could prod Federal Reserve officials away from their patient stance and toward cutting interest rates.

articles.title: Four Years After Beau Biden’s Death, His Father Bonds With Voters in Pain
articles.content: PHILADELPHIA — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has a habit of bringing people to tears.

articles.title: Uber’s First Earnings Report After I.P.O.: $1 Billion Loss
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s start as a publicly traded company has gone from bumpy to bumpier.

articles.title: The Week in Tech: Disinformation’s Huge Inaction Problem
articles.content: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

articles.title: Cedric Richmond, Biden’s New Co-Chairman, Sees a Path to the Nomination in the South
articles.content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign is naming Representative Cedric Richmond to a major leadership role within the organization, a move that could bolster Mr. Biden’s standing with some congressional Democrats and African-American leaders in politically important states, even as the former vice president faces scrutiny over his record on criminal justice issues.

articles.title: $146 Million Default by Nursing Home Chain Leaves U.S. on the Hook
articles.content: The cracks in the foundation of a Chicago nursing-home business began to appear almost immediately.

articles.title: Home Buyers See Signs of Relief This Spring
articles.content: Conditions are easing somewhat this spring for home shoppers, real estate experts say. Price increases are slowing. There are more properties for sale. And mortgage rates are low.

articles.title: Gun Issues, Long at the Fringe, Now Loom Large for Democratic Candidates
articles.content: WASHINGTON — For the first time in two decades, Democratic presidential candidates are engaged in a politically fraught debate on gun-control policy as campaigns and advocacy groups assess the nation’s evolving views of an issue long considered a land mine for the left.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Wants Congress to Ensure Presidents Can Be Indicted
articles.content: For many Democrats, the aftermath of the Mueller report raised one central question: Would Robert S. Mueller III have charged President Trump with a crime if Justice Department policy had not prevented him from doing so?

articles.title: As China Takes Aim, Silicon Valley Braces for Pain
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Silicon Valley looks west to China, it sees many things. More than a billion hungry consumers. A cheap source of labor. A competitor, partner, supplier and security risk.

articles.title: Trump’s Tariff Threat Sends Mexico, Lawmakers and Businesses Scrambling
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s threat to punish Mexico with tariffs until it restrains the flow of migrants rattled financial markets on Friday, and the Mexican government, American businesses and Republican lawmakers pressed Mr. Trump to back down.

articles.title: Lead a Major Automaker for 3 Years and You’re an Industry Elder
articles.content: When Dieter Zetsche was replaced as chief executive of Daimler last week, it underlined yet another momentous change in the automotive industry’s executive ranks.

articles.title: Lawsuit Could Cool a Fast-Growing Way of Giving to Charities
articles.content: When Emily and Malcolm Fairbairn decided to make a $100 million gift in 2017 to organizations that combat Lyme disease, they chose Fidelity Charitable, the country’s largest charity by assets, to distribute the money.

articles.title: Trump to Give Arthur Laffer, Tax-Cut Champion, the Presidential Medal of Freedom
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump will award the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to the economist Arthur Laffer, whose tax-cutting enthusiasm has shaped decades of Republican policymaking, including Mr. Trump’s.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From escalating trade wars to Mueller, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: Trump Administration Strips India of Special Trade Status
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced on Friday that it was stripping India of a special status that exempts billions of dollars of its products from American tariffs, part of a deepening clash over India’s protections for its market.

articles.title: Trump Is Said to Have Overruled Kushner and Other Aides in Threatening Mexico With Tariffs
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump pushed ahead with plans to impose tariffs  on Mexico over the objections of several top advisers, including his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, opting to side with hard-line officials who were advocating the move, according to multiple administration officials and people briefed on their plans.

articles.title: Justice Dept. Explores Google Antitrust Case
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is exploring whether to open a case against Google for potential antitrust violations, putting renewed scrutiny on the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of Big Tech, three people with knowledge of the deliberations said Friday.

articles.title: As Trade War Spreads to Mexico, Companies Lose a Safe Harbor
articles.content: When trade tensions with China flared last year, many companies sought refuge in a country with a long, stable relationship with the United States: Mexico.

articles.title: Boeing Built Deadly Assumptions Into 737 Max, Blind to a Late Design Change
articles.content: SEATTLE — The fatal flaws with Boeing’s 737 Max can be traced to a breakdown late in the plane’s development, when test pilots, engineers and regulators were left in the dark about a fundamental overhaul to an automated system that would ultimately play a role in two crashes.

articles.title: ‘You Don’t Have to Be in Des Moines.’ Democrats Expand Primary Map, Spurred by Social Media.
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Sunday marks exactly eight months until the Iowa caucuses, but only a single, long-shot Democratic candidate in the party’s sprawling field, Representative Tim Ryan, spent the weekend campaigning there.

articles.title: What Are Mexico’s Biggest Exports to the United States?
articles.content: It’s not just avocados.

articles.title: Twitter Takes Down Accounts of China Dissidents Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
articles.content: SHANGHAI — Three days before the most sensitive political anniversary on the Chinese calendar, Twitter suspended the accounts of Chinese political commentators in what it said was an accident. The move showed starkly the global political ramifications of Silicon Valley slip-ups.

articles.title: ‘Godzilla’ Sequel Disappoints, but Leaves a Bigger Footprint Overseas
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Even Godzilla needs a rest.

articles.title: California Is Now an ‘Early Primary State.’ Democrats Are Grappling With How to Compete.
articles.content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Senator Elizabeth Warren bounded onto stage before a crowd of more than 6,000 here — “the biggest one so far,” she announced excitedly — and stayed for nearly two extra hours, past 11 p.m., until everyone who wanted a picture with her had gotten one.

articles.title: Inside a Flashy Trump Project in Uruguay: Cash Shortages and Mismanagement
articles.content: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay — President Trump’s son Eric traveled in January to Punta del Este, a Uruguayan beach town on a spit of land jutting into the South Atlantic Ocean.

articles.title: Google and Amazon Are at the Center of a Storm Brewing Over Big Tech
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Google and Amazon have thrived as American regulators largely kept their distance. That may be changing.

articles.title: An HBO Question Is Giving AT&T Executives a Headache
articles.content: With its acquisition of Time Warner last year, AT&T was on its way toward creating a streaming service that will one day be the exclusive online home for “Game of Thrones” and the blockbuster film franchises centered on Wonder Woman, Batman and Harry Potter.

articles.title: Insurgent Democrats, Many of Them Women, Worry a New Party Policy Will Block Them
articles.content: WASHINGTON — A move by House Democratic leaders to thwart party members from mounting primary challenges to incumbents, even in safe Democratic districts, could have the unintended consequence of arresting the party’s shift toward a more female and racially diverse caucus, one of its most striking achievements of the last election.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders After Dark: Inside His First ‘Grass-Roots Fund-Raiser’
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Senator Bernie Sanders has long promised to run a different kind of campaign and be a different kind of president. On Saturday night, what was billed as his first “grass-roots fund-raiser” of the 2020 campaign was certainly different, as donor events go.

articles.title: As Slack Prepares to Go Public, Its C.E.O. Is Holding His Tongue
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Stewart Butterfield, chief executive of the workplace collaboration app Slack, once offended Robert De Niro at an awards event with an irreverent comment, prompting the actor to curse at him from the stage.

articles.title: China Strikes Defiant Stance on Trade Against Trump
articles.content: BEIJING — China struck a defiant stance on Sunday in response to President Trump’s growing pressure on trade, blaming the United States for a breakdown in negotiations and saying it must withdraw its latest round of tariffs before a deal can be reached.

articles.title: Kirsten Gillibrand, in Fox News Town Hall, Talks Abortion, Al Franken and More
articles.content: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York headlined a Fox News town-hall event Sunday, fielding questions on abortion, the #MeToo movement and gun control, and taking the opportunity to promote her flagging presidential candidacy on a network that frequently tops the cable news ratings.

articles.title: Hollywood Producer Seeks to Raise Funds to Battle Anti-Abortion Laws
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — One of Hollywood’s heaviest hitters, the producer and investor Peter Chernin, has started a campaign to raise millions of dollars to help fund a legal attack on new anti-abortion laws in Georgia and other states.

articles.title: Wall Street Pins Its Hopes on Fed Rate Cuts
articles.content: Traders are betting the Fed will bail them out again. If they’re wrong, things could get ugly.

articles.title: On Politics: California Is Now an Early Primary State
articles.content: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Trump Administration Considered Tariffs on Australia
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration considered imposing tariffs on imports from Australia last week, but decided against the move amid fierce opposition from military officials and the State Department, according to several people familiar with the discussions.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Big Tech’s Antitrust Reckoning Is Coming
articles.content: Good Monday. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Fiat and Renault Try to Reassure French Officials and Nissan
articles.content: PARIS — As Renault board members prepared to meet on Tuesday to consider a merger with Fiat Chrysler, the French government was scrambling to ensure that it would have influence over a proposed tie-up that could significantly change the balance of power in the global auto industry.

articles.title: Apple’s WWDC Highlights: the Death of iTunes and $6,000 Macs
articles.content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — In the history of Apple software, few services have been as important and influential as iTunes. It upended the music industry and popularized a new way to buy music, allowing people to purchase songs for a dollar.

articles.title: Trump Suggests a Boycott of AT&T to Punish CNN
articles.content: President Trump on Monday floated the notion of a consumer boycott of AT&T, the telecommunications firm turned media colossus, an apparent attempt to punish the company for the news coverage produced by one of its subsidiaries, CNN.

articles.title: Review: ‘Rockonomics’ Schools Us in the Costs and Benefits of Creativity
articles.content: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.title: A Farewell for iTunes
articles.content: Dearly beloved,

articles.title: Highlights of a House Bill’s Attempts to Help Retirees and Savers
articles.content: The retirement legislation that the House recently passed with an overwhelming bipartisan majority includes a series of provisions that would affect different groups of American savers and retirees. One change would open the door for complex annuity products to become part of your employer’s retirement offerings, but that’s just one provision.

articles.title: Confusing Options May Be Coming to Your 401(k). It Could Cost You.
articles.content: Americans may soon see some welcome changes to the rules governing their retirement savings plans, including the ability to contribute to their Individual Retirement Accounts longer or tap them to help pay for the arrival of a new child.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren Proposes ‘Aggressive Intervention’ to Create Jobs
articles.content: DETROIT — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts on Tuesday proposed an economic program of “aggressive intervention on behalf of American workers,” suggesting that as president she would invest $2 trillion in climate-friendly industries over a decade, create a new cabinet-level Department of Economic Development and even manipulate the dollar to promote exports.

articles.title: S.E.C. Sues Social-Media Company Kik Over Digital Coin Offering
articles.content: After the social-media start-up Kik Interactive sold $100 million worth of digital “coins” in 2017, the Canadian company argued that it didn’t need the permission of federal securities regulators.

articles.title: Apple Backs Off Crackdown on Parental-Control Apps
articles.content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Over the past year, Apple purged iPhone apps that helped people limit the amount of time they and their children spent on Apple devices, drawing accusations of anticompetitive behavior.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Big Tech Enters Antitrust Purgatory
articles.content: Good Tuesday. (Want this by email ? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Climate Change Takes Center Stage as Biden and Warren Release Plans
articles.content: WASHINGTON — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. was Barack Obama’s vice president, their administration brokered the landmark Paris climate accord and imposed the nation’s first federal regulations for cutting carbon dioxide emissions.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
articles.content: $13 MILLION

articles.title: 11,000 People Who Prepare Your Airline Food Are Considering a Strike
articles.content: President Trump announced a deal to end the government shutdown in January after a shortage of air traffic controllers briefly stopped flights into La Guardia Airport. At the time, many concluded that workers’ impact on travel had led the White House to retreat.

articles.title: In China, a Reuters Partner Blocks Articles on the Tiananmen Square Massacre
articles.content: A financial-information company partly owned by the news organization Thomson Reuters removed articles related to the June 4, 1989, Tiananmen Square massacre from the feeds of its data terminals in China last week. The move came under pressure from the Chinese government, Reuters reported Monday.

articles.title: YouTube to Remove Thousands of Videos Pushing Extreme Views
articles.content: YouTube announced plans on Wednesday to remove thousands of videos and channels that advocate neo-Nazism, white supremacy and other bigoted ideologies in an attempt to clean up extremism and hate speech on its popular service.

articles.title: S.E.C. Adopts New Broker Rules That Consumer Advocates Say Are Toothless
articles.content: Regulators have new rules for Wall Street brokers providing investment advice: Act in your customers’ best interest. But consumer advocates argue that the rules amount to little more than a new marketing slogan.

articles.title: Cory Booker’s Housing Plan Offers Tax Credit to Millions of Renters
articles.content: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey on Wednesday unveiled a plan to tackle affordable housing that would provide a tax credit for renters to ensure they would not spend more than 30 percent of their income on rent — a sweeping new entitlement program that his campaign estimated would reach 57 million Americans, including 17 million children.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren, on MSNBC, Calls Hyde Amendment an Assault on the ‘Most Vulnerable’ Women
articles.content: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, slowly gaining ground in the crowded Democratic presidential primary, appeared on MSNBC on Wednesday for a friendly town-hall event, which gave her ample opportunity to describe her signature policies and deliver some of her most reliable applause lines.

articles.title: On Politics: Senate Says No to Mexico Tariffs
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders: Two Liberals Aiming for the Same Target
articles.content: LANSING, Mich. — When Elizabeth Warren took the stage at a rally Tuesday evening, she brought with her the kind of populist economic message that had roused working-class voters here during the presidential race three years ago.

articles.title: Outside the U.S., It’s All About WhatsApp
articles.content: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Adam Satariano, a technology correspondent based in London, discussed the tech he’s using.

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler Withdraws Its Offer for Renault
articles.content: PARIS — Fiat Chrysler late Wednesday abruptly withdrew its proposal to merge with Renault, walking away from a deal that could have fundamentally reshaped the global auto industry.

articles.title: In China, a Viral Video Sets Off a Challenge to Rape Culture
articles.content: Richard Liu, the Chinese e-commerce billionaire, walked into an apartment building around 10 p.m., a young woman on his arm and his assistant in tow. Leaving the assistant behind, the young woman took Mr. Liu to an elevator. Then, she showed him into her apartment.

articles.title: Which States Will Be Hit Hardest by Trump’s Tariffs on Mexico
articles.content: President Trump’s plan to force Mexico to take a tougher approach to enforcement of its border, by ramping up tariffs on its products, will ripple through the United States, with consumers around the country paying more for cars, TVs, bluejeans, beer, fresh vegetables and other products.

articles.title: On Politics: Border Arrests at 7-Year High
articles.content: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Why Fiat Chrysler’s Talks With Renault Fell Apart
articles.content: The proposed merger of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Renault, a tie-up seen as a transformative deal in an industry facing technological challenges, fell apart on Wednesday, and the recriminations started almost immediately.

articles.title: Black Democrats Say It’s the Economy, Still
articles.content: A key base of support for the Democratic Party, black America, is lagging in its recovery from the recession and demanding more attention to economic issues than white voters. That divide could complicate presidential contenders’ attempts to woo African-American votes in 2020.

articles.title: Senators Ask Federal Reserve to Review Trump’s Deutsche Bank Transactions
articles.content: A group of Democratic senators wants top officials at the Federal Reserve to examine whether Deutsche Bank complied with anti-money-laundering and other laws after bank employees flagged transactions tied to President Trump as potentially suspicious.

articles.title: Google to Buy Data Analytics Company Despite New Antitrust Scrutiny
articles.content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Just as government officials step up their antitrust scrutiny of the American tech giants, Google had a surprising announcement on Thursday: It is buying another company.

articles.title: Election Rules Are an Obstacle to Cybersecurity of Presidential Campaigns
articles.content: One year out from the 2020 elections, presidential candidates face legal roadblocks to acquiring the tools and assistance necessary to defend against the cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns that plagued the 2016 presidential campaign.

articles.title: Democratic Candidates Woo Silicon Valley for Donations, Then Bash It
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Top Democrats in Washington and on the 2020 campaign trail are taking technology giants to task, calling them too big, too powerful and too careless about privacy. “The era of self-regulation is over,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared on Monday.

articles.title: Democratic Candidates Go After Joe Biden, but Not by Name
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The leading Democratic presidential contenders have begun criticizing Joseph R. Biden Jr. for, among other things, being too old, too moderate, too fixated on President Trump and too delusional about the state of the Republican Party. But you’d be forgiven if you missed it, because they almost never mention Mr. Biden by name.

articles.title: The Car Industry Is Under Siege
articles.content: FRANKFURT — It’s a scary time to be in the car business.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Why Fiat Chrysler Nixed the Renault Merger
articles.content: Good Thursday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

articles.title: S.E.C. Tells Brokers to Work for You, but Don’t Skip the Fine Print
articles.content: When you go to the doctor, there’s an expectation that she will act in your best interest. You don’t expect to be prescribed costly pills because the office is getting a commission from the drug company, when a healthier diet will do the trick.

articles.title: The 2020 Jeep Gladiator Barrels Into an Uncrowded Field: Midsize Pickups
articles.content: In a land where trucks often start at large and climb to supersize, the new hot thing is not an overpowered dreadnought but a midsize pickup from Jeep.

articles.title: New Evidence of Age Bias in Hiring, and a Push to Fight It
articles.content: MADISON, Ala. — Across the United States, mammoth corporations and family businesses share a complaint: a shortage of workers. As the unemployment rate has tunneled its way to a half-century low, employers insist they must scramble to lure applicants.

articles.title: Savings Accounts for Disabled Americans Catch On, but Slowly
articles.content: New state-based accounts that let disabled people work and save money without risking the loss of government aid are slowly catching on. But advocates say millions more people with disabilities could be taking advantage of the accounts.

articles.title: A Weak Jobs Report Poses a New Challenge to Trump: A Slowing Economy
articles.content: Lawmakers, business executives and economists have all tried to warn President Trump that his trade policies could hurt growth. On Friday, the government reported that employers added just 75,000 jobs in May, a fact that will be hard for him to ignore.

articles.title: Writing Cover Stories Is Hard. For Atlantic Editor, Talking About Diversity Is Harder.
articles.content: Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor in chief of The Atlantic, set off a storm of criticism Thursday when he suggested that, in seeking a diverse group of writers for cover stories, he had found it difficult to hand those plum assignments to anyone other than white male magazine journalists.

articles.title: Trade Wars Stoke Economic Fear as G-20 Finance Ministers Gather in Japan
articles.content: FUKUOKA, Japan — An unending trade war between the United States and China. President Trump’s weeklong threat to impose tariffs on Mexico. A potential clash with Europe over cars and agriculture.

articles.title: FedEx Says It’s Ending Express Shipping Service for Amazon
articles.content: It’s unusual when a major corporation boasts about its decision to cut back on doing business with Amazon.

articles.title: How A.I. Could Be Weaponized to Spread Disinformation
articles.content: The world’s top artificial intelligence labs are honing technology that can mimic how humans write, which could one day help disinformation campaigns go undetected by generating huge amounts of subtly different messages.

articles.title: Wells Fargo Agrees to Settle Auto Insurance Suit for $386 Million
articles.content: Wells Fargo has reached a $386 million deal to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by customers who say the bank forced them to buy unnecessary auto insurance, putting to rest one of its many legal problems.

articles.title: The Making of a YouTube Radical
articles.content: Caleb Cain was a college dropout looking for direction. He turned to YouTube, where he was pulled into a world filled with conspiracy theories, misogyny and racism.

articles.title: California Reckons With the Cost of Wildfires to Come
articles.content: SACRAMENTO — On a day when the latest California wildfire threat forced emergency precautions, a recently formed commission sent state officials a new blueprint for adapting to increasingly destructive fire seasons.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From Mexico to the United Kingdom, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: 3 New Policies From the 2020 Democrats: Policing, L.G.B.T. Rights and Voting Rights
articles.content: With 23 candidates in the Democratic presidential race, it can be hard to keep track of their policy proposals. This week alone, we’ve covered Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s climate change plan, Cory Booker’s housing plan and Elizabeth Warren’s economic plan in depth.

articles.title: China Summons Tech Giants to Warn Against Cooperating With Trump Ban
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The Chinese government this past week summoned major tech companies including Microsoft and Dell from the United States and Samsung of South Korea, to warn that they could face dire consequences if they cooperate with the Trump administration’s ban on sales of key American technology to Chinese companies, according to people familiar with the meetings.

articles.title: Behind Biden’s Reversal on Hyde Amendment: Lobbying, Backlash and an Ally’s Call
articles.content: ATLANTA — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. took the stage at a fund-raiser that drew many African-American Democrats Thursday night, he was under siege over his support for a measure that prohibits federal funding for most abortions.

articles.title: Trump Mixes Economic and National Security, Plunging the U.S. Into Multiple Fights
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump is increasingly blurring the line between America’s national and economic security, enabling him to harness powerful tools meant to punish the world’s worst global actors and redirect them at nearly every trading partner, including Mexico, Japan, China and Europe.

articles.title: United Technologies and Raytheon to Combine Into Aerospace and Military Giant
articles.content: United Technologies said on Sunday that it planned to combine its aerospace business with Raytheon, uniting the two into a new manufacturing giant in the worlds of aerospace and military weapons and aircraft.

articles.title: A Billboard No. 1 Is at Stake, So Here’s an Album With Your Taylor Swift Hoodie
articles.content: For decades, the phrase “No. 1 with a bullet” has referred to a song or album that zooms to the top of the Billboard charts. Given current music industry practices, “No. 1 with a T-shirt” may be more accurate.

articles.title: Biden Retains Lead in Iowa Poll, but Warren and Buttigieg Gain
articles.content: CRESCO, Iowa — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. retains a lead among likely Iowa caucusgoers, but both he and Senator Bernie Sanders have lost ground over the past three months while Senator Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Ind., have made clear gains, according to a new poll from The Des Moines Register and CNN.

articles.title: Wall Street Asks When, Not if, the Fed Will Cut Interest Rates
articles.content: The American economy is showing signs of cooling, and Wall Street is counting on Jerome H. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to come to the rescue.

articles.title: Google Made $4.7 Billion From the News Industry in 2018, Study Says
Kamala Harris, Seeking a Campaign Jolt, Defends Record as Prosecutor
articles.content: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C. — Senator Kamala Harris of California has, for months, faced criticism from activist Democrats who have said her record as California attorney general was at odds with her progressive reputation.

articles.title: Democrats Descend on Iowa for a Chance to Break Through
articles.content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Senators Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren took selfies — with each other. Senator Bernie Sanders marched with striking fast-food workers. Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., played the blues on an electric keyboard. And former Representative John Delaney brought a team of bagpipers.

articles.title: Electric Truck Company Workhorse Gets Needed Cash Infusion
articles.content: Workhorse, the electric truck maker involved in a proposed deal to acquire an idled General Motors factory in Ohio, said Monday that it had raised $25 million from investors.

articles.title: Trump Renews Attacks on Fed, Putting Central Bank in a Bind
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump renewed his criticism of the Federal Reserve on Monday, saying that the Fed erred in lifting interest rates last year and put the United States at a disadvantage to China.

articles.title: Delay in Huawei Ban Is Sought by White House Budget Office
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The acting budget chief for the White House has called for a two-year delay of part of a federal measure that is aimed at Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecom giant.

articles.title: Deutsche Bank Acknowledges Lapse in Checks on Money Laundering
articles.content: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank on Monday acknowledged a lapse in its money laundering controls, underlining the bank’s continuing struggle to move beyond a series of scandals that have helped push its stock price to a record low.

articles.title: Nissan and Renault Lock Horns as Relationship Sours Further
articles.content: TOKYO — The cracks in the world’s largest auto alliance grew wider on Monday, as Nissan Motor condemned as “most regrettable” a decision by its French partner, Renault, to withdraw support for the Japanese automaker’s efforts to overhaul its governance.

articles.title: Stocks Post Modest Gains as Trump’s Mexico Threat Eases
articles.content: Global markets rose modestly on Monday, as the prospect of a trade war between the United States and Mexico subsided.

articles.title: Huawei Tells Parliament It’s No Security Threat, Aiming to Avoid a Ban
articles.content: LONDON — A Huawei executive defended the company’s security practices in the face of tough questioning from members of the British Parliament on Monday, as the Chinese technology giant seeks to contain an American-led effort to ban it around the world.

articles.title: Making Data Coherent Drives Salesforce’s $15.3 Billion Deal for Tableau
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology vendors have been going on for years about the rising value of data. But information that can’t be understood is not worth much.

articles.title: How Much Will Age Matter in the 2020 Race?
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

Buttigieg Outlines Foreign Policy Views, Urging End to ‘Endless War’
articles.content: Pete Buttigieg lashed into President Trump on Tuesday for conducting foreign policy by tantrum and by tweet, as he called for the United States to rejoin the Iran nuclear deal, cease the “endless war” in Afghanistan and meet “the clear and present threat” of climate change.

articles.title: China Moves to Close Gap in Trade Expertise as Clash With Trump Intensifies
articles.content: BEIJING — Two weeks before talks between the United States and China broke down, Beijing quietly called one of its most formidable trade negotiators out of a pre-retirement posting.

articles.title: Rachel Maddow, Chuck Todd and Lester Holt Are Among Moderators of First Democratic Debate
articles.content: The first debate of the Democratic presidential primary will be moderated by the news anchors Savannah Guthrie, Lester Holt, Chuck Todd and José Díaz-Balart of Telemundo, along with the MSNBC commentator Rachel Maddow, NBC News said on Tuesday.

articles.title: As 2020 Candidates Struggle to Be Heard, Their Grumbling Gets Louder
articles.content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — When 19 presidential candidates descended on a hotel ballroom for an Iowa Democratic Party fund-raiser on Sunday, it seemed, at first glance, like a relatively collegial affair.

articles.title: Amazon to End Its Restaurant Delivery Service
articles.content: With the online restaurant delivery market growing ever more competitive, Amazon is discontinuing the service it started four years ago as an alternative to popular apps like Grubhub and UberEats.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump Sees Future in Tariffs
articles.content: Good Tuesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: New York Times’s Global Edition Is Ending Daily Political Cartoons
articles.content: The New York Times announced on Monday that it would no longer publish daily political cartoons in its international edition and ended its relationship with two contract cartoonists.

articles.title: Like Comic Books? This Platform Picks Titles for You
articles.content: Comic book fans have multiple digital options to choose from these days, with apps for independents, manga and political cartoons as well as libraries from giants like DC and Marvel. But the fractured nature of the business means readers have to visit several platforms to fill their needs.

articles.title: Trump Isn’t Alone. These Millennials on the Left Want Low Interest Rates, Too.
articles.content: As President Trump rails against the Federal Reserve and urges it to lower interest rates, a similar push is coming from a group founded this year by three left-leaning millennials — albeit for very different reasons.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders Calls His Brand of Socialism a Pathway to Beating Trump
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont offered a vigorous defense of the democratic socialism that has defined his five decades in political life on Wednesday, while tying his presidential campaign to the legacies of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Martin Luther King Jr.

articles.title: Planned Parenthood to Host Women’s Health Forum for 2020 Democrats
articles.content: Planned Parenthood Action Fund is set to host a forum on reproductive rights for the Democratic primary field this month, as the issue of abortion emerges as a central topic in the 2020 presidential race.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: T-Mobile’s Sprint Deal Is in Big Trouble
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Huawei Is Said to Demand Patent Fees From Verizon
articles.content: President Trump’s dispute with China has landed on the doorstep of Verizon, with Huawei demanding that the American wireless giant pay licensing fees on hundreds of patents, according to two people briefed on the matter.

articles.title: ‘Oversharing’ on Google Calendar, and Making Sure Readers Come Back for More
articles.content: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Jodi Rudoren, associate managing editor for audience, discussed the tech she’s using.

articles.title: Social Security Is Staring at Its First Real Shortfall in Decades
articles.content: A slow-moving crisis is approaching for Social Security, threatening to undermine a central pillar in the retirement of tens of millions of Americans.

articles.title: What Is Democratic Socialism? Whose Version Are We Talking About?
articles.content: Democratic socialism has become a major force in American political life. Just look at Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is planning a national address on Wednesday on what it is and why he believes it’s needed.

articles.title: On Politics: Biden vs. Trump
articles.content: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: The Safest Place in a Car Crash Isn’t the Back Seat Anymore
articles.content: For decades it was a given that the back seat of a car is the safest place in a crash. But that’s no longer certain, as advances in seatbelt technology up front have been slow to jump to the back seat.

articles.title: How Tanker Attacks in the Strait of Hormuz Could Affect Oil Prices
articles.content: The Strait of Hormuz, sometimes described as the world’s most important oil choke point, is a gateway for almost a third of all crude oil and other petroleum products carried by tanker.

articles.title: In the Race for Factory Jobs Under Trump, the Midwest Isn’t Winning
articles.content: In President Trump’s first two years in office, factory job growth accelerated, an achievement he has been claiming credit for ahead of the 2020 election, particularly in the industrial Midwest. His administration is “restoring American manufacturing,” Mr. Trump told workers at an Ohio factory in March.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Trump Finds an Unlikely Ally on Interest Rates
articles.content: Good Thursday morning. Breaking: Oil tankers were attacked in the Gulf of Oman this morning, sending oil prices higher. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

articles.title: On Politics: Congress and Trump Clash Over Census
articles.content: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Hey, Raptors Fans, You Want Fries With Those 3-Pointers?
articles.content: From an athletic point of view, the stakes on Thursday night were clear. It was Game 6 of the N.B.A. Finals, and the Toronto Raptors had their second chance in four days to clinch the franchise’s first title.

articles.title: Highlights From Julián Castro’s Fox News Town Hall
articles.content: Julián Castro became the fifth Democratic candidate for president to take a turn on the Fox News town-hall circuit on Thursday, and the topics were some of the cable network’s favorite catnip: immigration, abortion, the Steele dossier and Hillary Clinton.

articles.title: Joe Biden Said He Did Not View Abortion ‘As a Choice and a Right’ in 2006
articles.content: In a newly unearthed video from 2006, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he supported Roe v. Wade but did not view abortion as “a choice and a right” — remarks that raise further questions about how he views abortion rights as he runs for the Democratic presidential nomination and faces pressure over his position on the issue.

articles.title: Who’s In and Who’s Out of the First Debates
articles.content: [Update: Here are the lineups for the first two debate nights in late June.]

articles.title: Naomi Wolf’s Publisher Delays Release of Her Book
articles.content: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt is postponing the publication of Naomi Wolf’s forthcoming book “Outrages” after questions have been raised about the accuracy of her research.

articles.title: Car Stuck in the Shop? The New Waiting Room Has Movies and Manicures
articles.content: The waiting rooms attached to auto service departments tend to be dismal places, with stale coffee, patched seats, cable news on a flickering TV and last week’s copy of Sports Illustrated, if you’re lucky.

articles.title: What Is JAB? Owner of Panera, Snapple and Krispy Kreme Faces Its Nazi Past
articles.content: The average person probably hasn’t heard of JAB Holding. The same can’t be said for the vast empire of brands — a stable that includes Keurig coffee pods, Dr Pepper, Snapple, Einstein Bros. Bagels and Krispy Kreme doughnuts — it amassed in years of deal-making. Here’s how the conglomerate, whose controlling family is now grappling with its Nazi past, flourished.

articles.title: Sprint and T-Mobile Merger Approval, Said to Be Near, Could Undercut Challenge by States
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is moving closer to approving T-Mobile’s $26 billion merger with Sprint, but only if the companies sell multiple assets to create a new wireless competitor, according to three people familiar with the plan.

articles.title: When Rohingya Refugees Fled to India, Hate on Facebook Followed
articles.content: KOLKATA, India — Mohammad Salim, a Rohingya Muslim refugee, thought he had left genocidal violence and Facebook vitriol behind when he fled his native country, Myanmar, in 2013.

articles.title: Bribes and Backdoor Deals Help Foreign Firms Sell to China’s Hospitals
articles.content: BEIJING — A trip to the sauna. A golf club membership. Luxury watches. Neatly packed bricks of red Chinese bills worth $220,000.

articles.title: Stanford Team Aims at Alexa and Siri With a Privacy-Minded Alternative
articles.content: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It has been almost two decades since Google started to dominate internet search the way Microsoft dominated software for personal computers a generation earlier.

articles.title: Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner Report Up to $135 Million in 2018 Income
articles.content: In their second year of government service, Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner reported income from their companies and investments of as much as $135 million, according to their annual financial disclosure reports made public on Friday.

articles.title: Russia Sought to Use Social Media to Influence E.U. Vote, Report Finds
articles.content: LONDON — European authorities blamed Russian groups on Friday for disinformation campaigns designed to depress turnout and sway public opinion in last month’s European Union elections, an official accounting that underscored how Russian interference has not abated and that Facebook and other tech platforms remain vulnerable to meddling.

articles.title: Groundwork Is Laid for Opioids Settlement That Would Touch Every Corner of U.S.
articles.content: Every city, town and county in the United States could receive a payout in a settlement with the largest makers, distributors and retailers of prescription opioids, if a judge approves an innovative proposal made Friday in an Ohio federal court by lawyers for hundreds of local governments.

articles.title: How Secured Credit Cards Can Build, or Rebuild, Your Credit
articles.content: Once a little-known option, secured credit cards for people with scant or poor credit are getting more attention.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump Would Accept Russia’s Help
articles.content: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: India Raises Tariffs, Escalating Trade Fight With Trump
articles.content: MUMBAI, India — India announced late Saturday that it would raise tariffs on 28 categories of imports from the United States, the latest escalation in what has been a slow-motion trade fight between the two countries.

articles.title: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
articles.content: From the debates to Iran, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

articles.title: Volkswagen Factory Workers in Tennessee Reject Union
articles.content: In the latest defeat for organized labor in the South, workers at a Volkswagen plant in Tennessee rejected an effort to form a union this week.

articles.title: Democratic Candidates Promise to Close Wealth Gap Between Blacks and Whites
articles.content: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Four top Democratic presidential candidates promised black voters Saturday that, if elected, their administrations would help close the wealth gap between black and white Americans, continuing the growing trend of Democratic candidates and officials talking more explicitly about racial inequalities.

articles.title: Democratic Debates, Sanders on Socialism, New Polls: This Week in the 2020 Race
articles.content: We’re trying something new in our 2020 presidential campaign coverage.

articles.title: As Passions Flare in Abortion Debate, Many Americans Say ‘It’s Complicated’
articles.content: PITTSBURGH — Abortion is an issue that Lynndora Smith-Holmes goes back and forth on. “Six of one, half dozen of the other,” she said the other day as she finished her lunch break.

articles.title: ‘Who’s Taking Care of the Kids?’ Is Finally a Question for Dads on the Trail, Too
articles.content: [Sign up for our politics newsletter, and we’ll send you an invite to our live chat on debate night.]

articles.title: Handling of 737 Max Warning Light Was a ‘Mistake,’ Boeing C.E.O. Says
articles.content: Boeing’s chief executive said on Sunday that the company made a “mistake” in how it handled a cockpit warning light on the 737 Max. Dennis Muilenburg, the executive, made the comments while addressing reporters on the eve of the Paris Air Show, one of the most important sales events for aircraft manufacturers around the world.

articles.title: Wall Street Donors Are Swooning for Mayor Pete. (They Like Biden and Harris, Too.)
articles.content: The behind-the-scenes competition for Wall Street money in the 2020 presidential race is reaching a fevered peak this week as no less than nine Democrats are holding New York fund-raisers in a span of nine days, racing ahead of a June 30 filing deadline when they must disclose their latest financial hauls.

articles.title: ‘Catastrophic,’ ‘Cataclysmic’: Trump’s Tariff Threat Has Retailers Sounding Alarm
articles.content: Already battered by the e-commerce revolution, traditional retail stores are bracing for another blow — new tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports that the Trump administration is threatening to impose.

articles.title: Food-Delivery Couriers Exploit Desperate Migrants in France
articles.content: PARIS — Aymen Arfaoui strapped on a plastic Uber Eats bag and checked his cellphone for the fastest bicycle route before pedaling into the stream of cars circling the Place de la République. Time was money, and Mr. Arfaoui, a nervous 18-year-old migrant, needed cash.

articles.title: These Influencers Aren’t Flesh and Blood, Yet Millions Follow Them
articles.content: The kiss between Bella Hadid and Miquela Sousa, part of a Calvin Klein commercial last month, struck many viewers as unrealistic, even offensive.

articles.title: Mario Draghi Saved the Euro. Will His Successor Be Equally Committed?
articles.content: SINTRA, Portugal — Officially, the central bankers, economists and journalists converging on a golf resort outside Lisbon this week will be reflecting on the grand monetary experiment known as the euro, which turned 20 this year.

articles.title: Why Joe Biden Thinks He Can Ignore His Many Democratic Rivals
articles.content: MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa — In a field of 23 Democratic candidates for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is campaigning as if he is running alone.

articles.title: Why Sotheby’s Agreed to Be Bought by a Telecom Executive for $3.7 Billion
articles.content: LONDON — In recent years, the competition between the world’s two largest auction houses, Sotheby’s and Christie’s, has seemed at times like a bit of an unfair fight.

articles.title: Businesses Plead to Stop More China Tariffs. They Expect to Be Ignored.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Nervous business owners are spending seven days trying to persuade the Trump administration not to impose tariffs on an additional $300 billion worth of Chinese goods. Most are bracing for disappointment.

articles.title: J.J. Abrams Said to Be Near $500 Million Deal With WarnerMedia
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Sign with us. We can offer you spectacular opportunities. Have I mentioned how brilliant you are?

articles.title: 2020 Democrats Address Poverty and Systemic Racism at Presidential Forum
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. struck a notably different tone than some other Democrats on Monday over how to bring about change in government, defending his approach to working with Republicans during an appearance at a forum where he and eight other presidential candidates shared their views on addressing poverty.

articles.title: What Do You Want to See From the Democratic Debates?
articles.content: The 2020 Democratic primary race is moving into its next phase: the first debates are taking place over two nights next week and the lineup was announced on Friday. The campaigns are prepping their candidates and are trying to divine what voters want to hear.

articles.title: Huawei Chief Predicts Sales Will Flatline After Trump Crackdown
articles.content: SHANGHAI — Huawei, the embattled Chinese technology giant, is slashing its sales expectations for this year by around $25 billion as the Trump administration’s clampdown on the firm takes a bite out of its business.

articles.title: The True Price of the Thing You’re Buying May Not Be Printed on It
articles.content: What if the price of everything we bought included all of the things each item makes us feel?

articles.title: In Japan, It’s a Riveting TV Plot: Can a Worker Go Home on Time?
articles.content: TOKYO — Last month, as Americans tuned in to the final episode of “Game of Thrones,” Japan was indulging in its own television fantasy world.

articles.title: Here Is Where the Democratic Candidates Will Stand at the Debates
articles.content: First came the names of the 20 candidates who made the cut.

articles.title: Buttigieg Facing Test of Leadership After Shooting in South Bend
articles.content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Mayor Pete Buttigieg remained in South Bend, Ind., on Tuesday to confront a local crisis involving the fatal shooting of a black resident by a white police officer, skipping scheduled campaign appearances in Hollywood.

articles.title: Global Economic Growth Is Already Slowing. The U.S. Trade War Is Making It Worse.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s trade war is chilling business investment, confidence and trade flows across the world, a development that foreign leaders and business executives say is worsening a global economic slowdown that was already underway.

articles.title: Joe Biden Says His Campaign Has Raised Nearly $20 Million
articles.content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said at a fund-raiser in New York on Monday night that he had already amassed 360,000 donors with an average contribution of $55 — a disclosure that appeared to reveal he has raised $19.8 million for his presidential bid.

articles.title: How Libra, Facebook’s Cryptocurrency, Would Work for You
articles.content: Facebook and a consortium of 27 partners on Tuesday unveiled Libra, a new cryptocurrency. Their goal? To create a new global money and the foundation for a fresh universe of financial services.

articles.title: Trump Accuses Europe of Bolstering Its Economy at America’s Expense
articles.content: WASHINGTON — To President Trump, economics has always been a zero-sum game: If another country is winning, the United States must be losing.

articles.title: Joe Biden Visits Stonewall, Saying the Fight for L.G.B.T. Rights Must Continue
articles.content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. doesn’t drink alcohol, but on Tuesday afternoon he stood behind the bar at the Stonewall Inn in New York City, buying a round of beers.

articles.title: On Politics: Iran Threatens to Exceed Nuclear Limits
articles.content: Good Tuesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: BuzzFeed News Is Part of a Union Wave at Digital Media Outlets
articles.content: Expertise in the language of the internet is part of what has made BuzzFeed a digital giant. Now members of the website’s news staff are using their fluency in digital culture to pressure their employer to come to the bargaining table.

articles.title: Stocks Inch Closer to Record as Fed Signals Willingness to Cut Rates
articles.content: Stocks edged higher Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve indicated that a growing number of the central bank’s policymakers now expect to cut interest rates this year.

articles.title: Black Superstars Pitch Adidas Shoes. Its Black Workers Say They’re Sidelined.
articles.content: In the United States, Adidas has built much of its name — and sales — through its association with black superstars. In the 1980s, the seminal hip-hop group Run-DMC gave the company’s sneakers and apparel cultural cachet through its song “My Adidas.” Popular black athletes and entertainers like James Harden, Candace Parker and Kanye West endorse its products.

articles.title: $24.8 Million Raised in 24 Hours: Trump Adds to His Financial Advantage
articles.content: President Trump’s campaign announced Wednesday that he had raised $24.8 million over 24 hours as he kicked off his re-election bid, an enormous haul that punctuates the financial advantage he is expected to enjoy over his Democratic challengers in 2020.

articles.title: South Carolina Will Host 21 Presidential Candidates, and C-Span Can’t Do Live Coverage
articles.content: It takes a lot for C-Span to get mad.

articles.title: Globalization Is Moving Past the U.S. and Its Vision of World Order
articles.content: LONDON — If globalization were ever going to unravel, the beginning would probably feel something like this.

articles.title: Boeing Criticized for 737 Max Crisis at House Hearing
articles.content: Boeing has “caused a global aviation crisis of trust,” the head of a pilots union said during a congressional hearing on Wednesday in which lawmakers, pilots and airline officials expressed frustration even as the company makes progress in returning its 737 Max jet to service.

articles.title: F.T.C. Said to Be Investigating YouTube Over Child Privacy Claims
articles.content: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of an investigation into YouTube’s handling of videos aimed at children, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

articles.title: We Put the 2020 Democrats on the Spot. Here’s What We Learned.
articles.content: We spent hours interviewing the enormous Democratic presidential field on subjects ranging from climate change and border control to fast food and personal humiliation. And while many Democrats agree on a broad set of political ideas, there were some telling differences and disclosures that emerged from our conversations. Here are a few of our takeaways.

articles.title: Joe Biden Called Cory Booker. But Apologize? It’s Not the Biden Way.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — From his treatment of Anita Hill in the 1990s to his unwelcome hugs of women, from his recent flip-flop on abortion funding to his latest remarks about segregationists, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has spent the early months of his third presidential bid doing a lot of explaining, justifying and pushing back.

articles.title: Cory Booker Proposes Clemency for Thousands of Nonviolent Drug Offenders
articles.content: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey on Thursday announced a plan to offer clemency to more than 17,000 inmates serving time for nonviolent drug-related offenses on the first day of his presidency, an expansive use of executive power that would be the broadest clemency initiative since the Civil War.

articles.title: A ‘Sorceress’ in Brazil, a ‘Wink’ in India: Walmart Pleads Guilty After a Decade of Bribes
articles.content: Inside Walmart’s corporate offices in Brazil, one local contact was known as the “sorceress” for the ability to obtain government permits quickly.

articles.title: New York Union Throws Weight Behind ‘Hometown Guy’ Bill de Blasio for 2020
articles.content: A hotel union in New York is readying one of the first outside spending campaigns of the Democratic primary for president, promising to commit hundreds of thousands of dollars in the coming weeks to boost the prospects of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

articles.title: Slack Stock Soars, Putting Company’s Public Value at $19.5 Billion
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Slack shares soared on Thursday on its first day of trading on the stock market, in a sign that Wall Street remains tantalized by fast-growing young technology firms even after the recent lackluster public offerings of larger companies like Uber.

articles.title: Stocks Just Hit a Record, Thanks to the Fed
articles.content: It’s the Fed to the rescue. Again.

articles.title: Renault and Nissan Make Peace in a Deal to Tighten Oversight
articles.content: Renault announced on Thursday that it had settled a core dispute in its rocky relationship with Nissan ahead of a pivotal meeting of Nissan shareholders next week in Japan, in a deal that officials hope will allow both companies to focus on strengthening the world’s largest auto alliance.

articles.title: Inside Our 2020 Candidate Video Project
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: As Hong Kong Erupted Over Extradition Bill, City’s Tycoons Waited and Worried
articles.content: HONG KONG — Weeks before this semiautonomous city erupted in political chaos over a contentious extradition bill, more than 200 of its most powerful business leaders were summoned to the Chinese government’s headquarters here.

articles.title: The Oil Market Shows It Can Take a Punch
articles.content: So far, this isn’t your typical oil crisis.

articles.title: Fed Officials Make the Case for Cutting Interest Rates as Risks Loom
articles.content: Federal Reserve officials on Friday outlined the case for an interest-rate cut, making clear in their first public remarks since the central bank chose to leave policy unchanged this week that inflation and rising global risks are weighing heavily on their minds.

articles.title: Buttigieg Leaves Campaign Trail After Fatal Shooting. Reality Rears Its Head.
articles.content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — While his 2020 rivals mingled with large friendly crowds at a Democratic fish fry in South Carolina Friday night, Mayor Pete Buttigieg found himself somewhere very different, wading into an emotional knot of protesters at the South Bend Police Department, some of whom cursed him, interrupted him and shouted a list of demands through a megaphone feet from his face.

articles.title: The Gender Gap in Computer Science Research Won’t Close for 100 Years
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Women will not reach parity with men in writing published computer science research in this century if current trends hold, according to a study released on Friday.

articles.title: U.S. Blacklists More Chinese Tech Companies Over National Security Concerns
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration added five Chinese entities to a United States blacklist on Friday, further restricting China’s access to American technology and stoking already high tensions before a planned meeting between President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China in Japan next week.

articles.title: On Politics: Trump Calls Off Strikes on Iran
articles.content: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Biden Has Not Changed. The Politics, Culture and Mood of His Party Have.
articles.content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was addressing an elite audience, describing how as a young senator he had learned to work with Jesse Helms, the right-wing North Carolinian known for his fierce opposition to civil rights and his open loathing of gay people. He once believed Mr. Helms had “no redeeming social value,” Mr. Biden said, until a senior Democratic senator chided him, explaining that Mr. Helms and his wife had adopted a disabled teenager.

articles.title: Seeking $2.1 Million After College Chain’s Collapse (to Repay Its Guardian, Not Students)
articles.content: When Dream Center Education Holdings imploded in March, thousands of students and employees of the large college chain were suddenly locked out of their classrooms. Some $16 million in federal financial aid that was owed to students had disappeared, while landlords, teachers and vendors faced hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid bills.

articles.title: ‘The Black Vote Is Not Monolithic’: 2020 Democrats Find Split Preferences in South Carolina
articles.content: McCLELLANVILLE, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. enjoys a sizable advantage with black voters in South Carolina right now, and not just at lunch tables where they discuss candidates over freshly caught shrimp and fried fish. Recent polls have shown him with support from about 50 percent of African-American voters in the state.

articles.title: Biden, in Interview with Sharpton, Tries to Defuse Criticism of Remarks on Segregationists
articles.content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Saturday sought to tamp down anger over his praise for the bygone civility of a Senate that included notorious segregationists, stopping just short of an apology while asserting that his reference to never being called “boy” by one of the senators was not racial in nature.

articles.title: L.A. to Vegas and Back by Electric Car: 8 Hours Driving; 5 More Plugged In
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — You’ve heard it many times, from automakers, the energy industry and government officials: Electric vehicles are the cars of the future, essential to the fight against climate change.

articles.title: Artists Sue Universal Music Group Over Losses in 2008 Fire
articles.content: A group of high-profile pop musicians and estates sued the Universal Music Group on Friday over a 2008 fire that destroyed thousands of archived recordings but, according to the lawsuit, was never disclosed to the artists.

articles.title: What the 2020 Democrats Are Like Behind the Scenes
articles.content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

articles.title: Trump Kicks Off 2020, Biden’s Backlash, Warren on Prisons: This Week in the 2020 Race
articles.content: We’re trying something new in our 2020 presidential campaign coverage.

articles.title: What Happens After Amazon’s Domination Is Complete? Its Bookstore Offers Clues
articles.content: SPERRYVILLE, Va. — “The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy” is a medical handbook that recommends the right amount of the right drug for treating ailments from bacterial pneumonia to infected wounds. Lives depend on it.

articles.title: In Streaming Age, Classical Music Gets Lost in the Metadata
articles.content: When Roopa Kalyanaraman Marcello, a classical music aficionado in Brooklyn, asked her Amazon Echo for some music recently, she had a specific request: the third movement of Beethoven’s “Emperor” Concerto.

articles.title: ‘Medicare for All’ vs. ‘Public Option’: The 2020 Field Is Split, Our Survey Shows
articles.content: “Medicare for all” is the hottest idea in the Democratic presidential race for overhauling the nation’s health care system, and it is a phrase quite likely to be heard repeatedly at the first debates this week. But despite all the buzz, it turns out that the concept is dividing the 2020 field.

articles.title: How the Democratic Candidates Responded to a Health Care Policy Survey
articles.content: The New York Times asked all 23 Democratic presidential candidates for their views on the best ways to improve the health care system. We received responses from 19 of them.

articles.title: At Town Hall, Pete Buttigieg Confronts Tensions Around South Bend Police Shooting
articles.content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — It has been one of the biggest challenges for Pete Buttigieg since he began his improbable presidential campaign in January: Could the Harvard-educated mayor of South Bend, who often comes across like the brainy technocrat he once was as a McKinsey & Company consultant, build a following among black voters, one of the Democratic Party’s most vital constituencies?

articles.title: 5 Lessons From Microsoft’s Antitrust Woes, by People Who Lived It
articles.content: The nation’s antitrust enforcers and Congress are stepping up their scrutiny of the tech giants. Disruptive investigations, federal lawsuits and new rules could loom for Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple.

articles.title: Bookstores Find Growth as ‘Anchors of Authenticity’
articles.content: On a recent Sunday evening in the basement of McNally Jackson Independent Booksellers in New York’s Nolita neighborhood, some 40 people gathered in a 12-by-20-foot space surrounded by movable bookshelves to hear Julia Phillips discuss her novel, “Disappearing Earth.”

articles.title: A Machine May Not Take Your Job, but One Could Become Your Boss
articles.content: When Conor Sprouls, a customer service representative in the call center of the insurance giant MetLife talks to a customer over the phone, he keeps one eye on the bottom-right corner of his screen. There, in a little blue box, A.I. tells him how he’s doing.

articles.title: Lyft and Uber Were Duds, but the I.P.O. Market Is Having a Great Year

articles.title: Eldorado Resorts to Merge With Caesars in $17 Billion Casino Deal
articles.content: The casino operator Eldorado Resorts has agreed to merge with Caesars Entertainment in a $17.3 billion cash-and-stock deal, including debt, the companies said on Monday, in a bid to create the country’s largest casino operator.

articles.title: Ann Sarnoff, a Hollywood Outsider, Will Lead Warner Bros. Studio
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — AT&T on Monday chose a Hollywood outsider, Ann Sarnoff, to run its recently acquired Warner Bros. movie and television studio, which will play a major role in the conglomerate’s coming streaming service.

articles.title: Welcome to Debate Week
articles.content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: Chinese Drones Made in America: One Company’s Plan to Win Over Trump
articles.content: WASHINGTON — DJI, the large Chinese drone maker, is facing mounting security concerns within the Trump administration that its flying machines could send sensitive surveillance data back to China. Now, the company is trying to get on American officials’ good side by building some products in the United States.

articles.title: Trump’s Feud With the Fed Is Rooted in Presidential History
articles.content: President Trump has made heckling the Federal Reserve, and its chair, Jerome H. Powell, something of a sport. He has berated Mr. Powell for raising interest rates and taking steps to end a crisis-era stimulus program, likening the Fed to a powerful golfer who has “no touch” and cannot win.

articles.title: 2 Big Book and Magazine Printers Face Suit to Block Their Merger
articles.content: The printed page has seen better days.

articles.title: For Erdogan, the Bill for Turkey’s Debt-Fueled Growth Comes Due
articles.content: ISTANBUL — The shocking rebuke of Turkey’s governing party in Sunday’s mayoral election in Istanbul resonated as more than a yearning for new leadership in the nation’s largest city. It signaled mounting despair over the economic disaster that has befallen the nation under the strongman rule of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

articles.title: On Politics: U.S. Working on Clandestine Plans for Iran
articles.content: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

articles.title: Gender Gap Closes When Everyone’s on the Ballot, Study Shows
articles.content: Since Jeannette Rankin became the first woman elected to Congress in 1916, the numbers game for women in elected office has been marked by largely glacial progress. But a new report lays out the extent to which women and people of color have gained ground in elections around the country over the last two years.

articles.content: The millennial generation attended college in a golden era for student housing, as investors poured money into luxurious off-campus communities packed with resort-style amenities: rooftop pools, golf simulators, tanning beds, climbing walls.

articles.title: Condé Nast Sells W Magazine; Stefano Tonchi Out as Top Editor
articles.content: The magazine giant Condé Nast said on Tuesday that it had found a buyer for the bimonthly fashion title W, one of three publications the company put up for sale last year in the face of significant financial losses that forced it to adopt a series of cost-cutting measures.

articles.title: Is Cory Booker Too Nice? (And Is That Bad?)
articles.content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Senator Cory Booker has for months been looking for his breakout moment, the opportunity to stand out from the sprawling Democratic presidential field, go viral online, and reap the benefits in the polls and with a surge of new contributors.

articles.title: U.S. Tech Companies Sidestep a Trump Ban, to Keep Selling to Huawei
articles.content: SHANGHAI — United States chip makers are still selling millions of dollars of products to Huawei despite a Trump administration ban on the sale of American technology to the Chinese telecommunications giant, according to four people with knowledge of the sales.

articles.title: Debates Mark the Starting Line for the Media’s Race Through 2020
articles.content: MIAMI — For all of the cable news chatter, Twitter skirmishes and presidentially bestowed nicknames, this week’s prime-time Democratic debates mark the entry point for millions of Americans who are just now tuning into a presidential contest that will dominate news coverage for the next 16 months.
