articles.title: Nissan Reappoints Saikawa to Board as Shareholders Hammer Renault
articles.content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Nissan’s embattled chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa, was re-elected to the company’s board on Tuesday, during an annual meeting in which shareholders vented their anger at the scandal-wracked company’s French partner, Renault.

articles.title: Kenneth Lerer Steps Down as BuzzFeed Chairman
articles.content: Kenneth Lerer, a prolific investor who helped found HuffPost, has stepped down as chairman of BuzzFeed, the viral-happy website that has lately experienced turbulence after a sharp rise in prominence.

articles.title: Botox Maker Allergan Is Sold to AbbVie in $63 Billion Deal
articles.content: The drugmaker AbbVie said on Tuesday that it planned to buy Allergan, the maker of Botox, for about $63 billion, in one of the biggest mergers in the health care industry this year.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Sidestepping the Huawei Ban
articles.content: Good Wednesday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

articles.title: Steve Bullock, Locked Out of the Debate, Sees a Path Forward in the 2020 Race
articles.content: NASHUA, N.H. — Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana spent last weekend apart from the rest of the Democratic presidential field, which gathered in South Carolina. While the top 20 candidates are in Miami for the first primary debates this week, he isn’t  there, either.

articles.title: ‘My Plan B Is Maybe My Plan A’: Trump Threatens New Tariffs on China
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday played down the importance of securing a trade deal with China as he prepared to meet with its president, Xi Jinping, saying he was ready to proceed with additional tariffs if negotiations between the countries failed to get back on track.

articles.title: 7 Takeaways From the June 26 Democratic Debate: Castro’s Big Night
articles.content: Night One of the first Democratic debate of the 2020 race is in the books. There was no standout moment for any of the 10 candidates; no one suffered real damage either. While the NBC moderators tried to get the moderate and liberal Democrats to criticize each other, they were polite for the most part and stuck to their preferred issues and messages.

articles.title: Google and the University of Chicago Are Sued Over Data Sharing
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — When the University of Chicago Medical Center announced a partnership to share patient data with Google in 2017, the alliance was promoted as a way to unlock information trapped in electronic health records and improve predictive analysis in medicine.

articles.title: How 21 Democratic Candidates Answered Our Questions Before the Debates
articles.content: Which Democratic candidates believe that the next president could stop climate change? Which candidates don’t believe that?

articles.title: Here Are the Lineups for the First 2020 Democratic Debates
articles.content: This first Democratic debates of the 2020 race have arrived, taking place Wednesday and Thursday nights from 9 to 11 p.m., with 10 candidates from the sprawling field of 24 debating each night.

articles.title: Buy Low-Tops, Sell High-Tops: StockX Sneaker Exchange Is Worth $1 Billion
articles.content: Nic Wilkins started selling parts of his sneaker collection online two years ago as a way to make some extra cash in college. The hobby took off, and this year he expects to move 10,000 pairs of shoes. His anticipated take is a 25 percent profit from over $1 million in sales.

articles.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Taking Your Smartphone Abroad for Cheap
articles.content: Don’t even think about leaving your smartphone at home this summer if you are traveling to a foreign country.

articles.title: ‘Talk Is Meaningless’: Readers Tell Us What They Want From the Debates
articles.content: We wanted to hear from voters on their expectations for the Democratic debates, so we asked readers to tell us how they would be judging the candidates’ performances and what issues they would most like to hear about. We received more than 500 responses. Many respondents self-identified as registered Democrats and said that although they voted for Hillary Clinton in the general election, they voted for Senator Bernie Sanders in the primary.

articles.title: There Were 3 Women Onstage, and a Man Had a Lot to Say About His Work on Abortion
articles.content: It took 30 minutes or so for Senator Elizabeth Warren to wind toward well-worn territory for her: a riff on the evils of insurance companies. “It’s not working for families,” she said, “But it’s sure as heck working for them. It’s time for us to make families come first.”

articles.title: Julián Castro Is Crowned the Winner on Telemundo’s First Debate Night
articles.content: On the crowded debate stage, two presidential hopefuls offered up answers in Spanish — however imperfect — early in the evening.

articles.title: Debate Night: Join The Times’s Live Chat
articles.content: Welcome to a special debate night edition of On Politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: Jony Ive, Designer Who Made Apple Look Like Apple, Is Leaving to Start a Firm
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Jony Ive, Apple’s chief design officer and one of the most influential executives in the history of the Silicon Valley giant, is leaving the company.

articles.title: 6 Highlights From Night 2 of the Democratic Debates
Michigan Republicans Tune In to Democratic Debate. No Conversions Reported.
articles.content: PORTAGE, Mich. — Not everyone watching Wednesday’s Democratic debate was looking for a hero.

articles.title: Michael Bennet on Washington Corruption and Gridlock
articles.content: Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, 54, is participating in the Democratic primary’s second debate on Thursday in Miami. He is a moderate who gained national attention after delivering a passionate speech on the Senate floor during a government shutdown.

articles.title: The Cars Are Newer, the Buyers Younger as Auto Collecting Moves Forward
articles.content: When Kurt Glaubitz bought a vintage British automobile, it wasn’t for its sweeping curves or coach-built looks. Despite its scrawny-necked snorkel (for fording rivers) and boxy lines, however, his 1992 Land Rover Defender fits right into the latest wave of cars being scooped up by a new generation of collectors.

articles.title: Twitter to Label Abusive Tweets From Political Leaders
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter announced on Thursday that it would hide messages from major political figures who break the company’s rules for harassment or abuse behind a warning label, but would not take the messages down, in a move that could exacerbate the debate over political bias on the service.

articles.title: Nissan of Japan Discloses a New Recall, Adding to Its Problems
articles.content: TOKYO — Nissan revealed two new blows to its embattled management on Thursday, as it announced a recall of 490,000 vehicles in Japan and disclosed that its shareholders remained split over its chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa.

articles.title: Joe Biden on Crime and Mass Incarceration
articles.content: As Joseph R. Biden Jr. makes his third run for the White House, he is being pressed  to answer for his role in legislation that criminal justice experts  say helped lay the groundwork for the mass incarceration that has devastated America’s black communities.

articles.title: Pete Buttigieg and the South Bend Police
articles.content: Thirteen weeks after taking office, Pete Buttigieg fired South Bend’s popular African-American police chief. The episode threatened his standing with some black people in South Bend, a relationship that was further strained this month when a white police officer killed a black man there.

articles.title: Kamala Harris on the LIFT Act
articles.content: In late 2018, Senator Kamala Harris of California announced a proposal called the LIFT the Middle Class Act, a piece of legislation aimed at addressing the rising cost of living by providing middle-class and working families with a significant tax credit. She has been highlighting her proposal on the campaign trail as she seeks the Democratic nomination for president.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders on Health Care Costs
articles.content: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and other 2020 candidates often note that the United States spends twice as much on health care as other comparable nations but gets less value in return.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders on Drug Costs
articles.content: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont frequently assails the cost of prescription drugs, citing the statistic that one in five Americans cannot afford them. He has called for prices to be cut in half.

articles.title: Debate Night 2: The ‘On Politics’ Breakdown
articles.content: Hi, and welcome to a special post-debate edition of On Politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

articles.title: The World’s Top Stock Market? Right Now, It’s Russia
articles.content: Bragging rights for the world’s hottest major stock market this year belong to an unlikely leader: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

articles.title: Reparations Are Part of Marianne Williamson’s Plan to Heal America
articles.content: As part of the self-help author Marianne Williamson’s campaign to heal America, she has proposed paying $200 billion to $500 billion in reparations for slavery over a period of 20 years.

articles.title: A Path to Discovery in the Theranos Case
articles.content: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.title: Buttigieg’s Debate Remarks on Police Shooting Don’t Satisfy Some Back Home
articles.content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — It was more than an hour into Thursday’s Democratic debate before the community activists watching back home finally heard Mayor Pete Buttigieg face the tough questions they were waiting for.

articles.title: Mom, Can I Stay Up to Prepare for My Pitch?
articles.content: Lucy Lareau is excited about the publication of her latest book, this one on monarch butterflies. Conceiving, writing, editing and promoting it required hard work — all while she was finishing the seventh grade.

articles.title: Liberal Democrats Ruled the Debates. Will Moderates Regain Their Voices?
articles.content: The Democratic debates this past week provided the clearest evidence yet that many of the leading presidential candidates are breaking with the incremental politics of the Clinton and Obama eras, and are embracing sweeping liberal policy changes on some of the most charged public issues in American life, even at the risk of political backlash.

articles.title: Kamala Harris Raises $2 Million in 24 Hours After Debate
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Senator Kamala Harris of California raised $2 million online in the first 24 hours following the start of Thursday’s presidential primary debate, a total that suggests her performance resonated with many Democratic donors.

articles.title: Boeing’s Dreamliner Plant Is Said to Face Federal Inquiry
articles.content: The Department of Justice, which has been looking into problems with Boeing’s 737 Max jet, has broadened its investigation to include the production of the company’s 787 Dreamliner, according to two people familiar with the matter.

articles.title: Democrats Veer Left on Immigration at Debates, Pleasing Base (and Trump)
articles.content: For an issue as thorny and vexing as immigration policy, a question during the Democratic debate on Thursday was remarkably clear.

articles.title: OPEC and Russia Seek to Support the Price of Oil
articles.content: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries doesn’t stir as much fear in oil markets it once did, but it still has the power to shake up oil prices.

articles.title: Debate Over Uber and Lyft Drivers’ Rights in California Has Split Labor
articles.content: California’s labor movement recently seemed on the verge of a new era for worker rights. A state court ruled that workers in the gig economy should have many of the protections of employment, like a minimum wage and overtime pay. And the State Assembly passed a bill codifying that ruling and adding more protections.

articles.title: A China-U.S. Trade Truce Could Enshrine a Global Economic Shift
articles.content: OSAKA, Japan — The spin from President Trump and China’s propaganda machines on Saturday portrayed a truce in a trade war that has shaken economies and markets around the world. Tariffs won’t rise further, at least not yet. And the United States will loosen its potentially devastating punishments against Huawei, China’s most successful multinational company.

articles.title: Glaad’s Bold New Campaign: an L.G.B.T. Constitutional Amendment
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Glaad almost died in 2014.

articles.title: Debates, Voting Rights, Yet Another Candidate: This Week in the 2020 Race
articles.content: Every Saturday morning, we’re publishing “This Week in the 2020 Race”: a quick way to follow the presidential campaign and the field of 24 candidates for the Democratic nomination. Trust us, we know how hard it is to keep up.

articles.title: DealBook Special: Wall Street’s Unexpectedly Hot First Half of 2019
articles.content: Good Sunday morning, and welcome to a special edition of the DealBook Briefing where we’ll take a look at how Wall Street and the wider world of finance has performed during the first six months of 2019. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

articles.title: E.U. Signs Trade Deal With Vietnam
articles.content: The European Union signed a trade deal with Vietnam on Sunday, underscoring the bloc’s commitment to opening up its market and trading freely in the face of rising protectionism and trade tensions around the world.

articles.title: U.S. Oil Companies Find Energy Independence Isn’t So Profitable
articles.content: HOUSTON — For decades, elected leaders and corporate executives have chased a dream of independence from unstable or unfriendly foreign oil producers. Mission accomplished: Oil companies are producing record amounts of crude oil and natural gas in the United States and have become major exporters.
